The companies collaborated on development of the Airbus range, but guarded the financial details of their own production activities and sought to maximise the transfer prices of their sub-assemblies.<ref name="awst formation"/> It was becoming clear that Airbus was no longer a temporary collaboration to produce a single plane as per its original mission statement, it had become a long term brand for the development of further aircraft. By the late 1980s work had begun on a pair of new medium-sized aircraft, the biggest to be produced at this point under the Airbus name, the [[Airbus A330]] and the [[Airbus A340]].<ref>Frawley, Gerald. "Airbus A330-200". "Airbus A330-300". ''The International Directory of Civil Aircraft, 2003/2004''. Aerospace Publications, 2003. {{ISBN|1-875671-58-7}}.</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Airbus faces critical decision in coming months |agency=Reuters |date=26 December 2001 |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=CSTB&p_theme=cstb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB36D3CA3B32C67&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}}</ref> In the early 1990s the then Airbus CEO Jean Pierson argued that the GIE should be abandoned and Airbus established as a conventional company.<ref>{{cite press release |title=Airbus Tries to Fly in a New Formation;Consortium's Chief Hopes a Revamping Could Aid Its Challenge to Boeing |work=The New York Times |date=2 May 1996 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/02/business/international-business-airbus-tries-fly-new-formation-consortium-s-chief-hopes.html?pagewanted=all | first=John | last=Tagliabue | accessdate=23 April 2010}}</ref> However, the difficulties of integrating and valuing the assets of four companies, as well as legal issues, delayed the initiative. In December 1998, when it was reported that British Aerospace and DASA were close to merging,<ref>{{cite news |last=Spiegel |first =Peter |title=End of an era at BAE: how Sir Richard Evans changed the UK defence industry |work=Financial Times |date =17 July 2004}}</ref> AÃ©rospatiale paralysed negotiations on the Airbus conversion; the French company feared the combined BAe/DASA, which would own 57.9% of Airbus, would dominate the company and it insisted on a 50/50 split.<ref>{{cite news|title=Platform envy |work=The Economist |date=12 December 1998}}</ref> However, the issue was resolved in January 1999 when BAe abandoned talks with DASA in favour of merging with [[Marconi Electronic Systems]] to become [[BAE Systems]].<ref>{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/239057.stm |title = GEC spoils DASA / BAe party |publisher=BBC News |date = 20 December 1998 | accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-Navy-International-99/BRITISH-AEROSPACE-AND-MARCONI-ELECTRONIC-SYSTEMS-FORM-THE-THIRD-LARGEST-DEFENCE-UNIT-IN-THE-WORLD.html |title = British Aerospace and Marconi Electronic Systems form the third largest defence unit in the world |publisher=Jane's International |date = 19 January 1999}}</ref><ref name="scotsman2000"/> Then in 2000 three of the four partner companies ([[DaimlerChrysler Aerospace]], successor to Deutsche Airbus; [[AÃ©rospatiale-Matra]], successor to Sud-Aviation; and CASA) merged to form EADS, simplifying the process. EADS now owned Airbus France, Airbus Deutschland and Airbus EspaÃ±a, and thus 80% of Airbus Industrie.<ref name="awst formation"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eads.eu/1024/en/eads/history/chronos/2000.html |title=History of EADS |publisher=EADS |accessdate=7 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603121737/http://www.eads.eu/1024/en/eads/history/chronos/2000.html |archivedate=3 June 2008 }}</ref> BAE Systems and EADS transferred their production assets to the new company, Airbus <small>SAS</small>, in return for shareholdings in that company.<ref name="awst formation"/><ref>{{cite press release|title=EADS and BAE SYSTEMS complete Airbus integration â Airbus SAS formally established |publisher=BAE Systems plc |date=12 July 2001 |url=http://www.baesystems.com/Newsroom/NewsReleases/2001/press_120720011.html |accessdate=4 October 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020052508/http://baesystems.com/Newsroom/NewsReleases/2001/press_120720011.html |archivedate=20 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Development of the A380=== {{Main|Airbus A380}} <div class="floatleft"> <timeline> ImageSize = width:275 height:210 PlotArea = left:50 right:0 bottom:10 top:10 DateFormat = yyyy Period = from:1991 till:2007 TimeAxis = orientation:vertical ScaleMajor = unit:year increment:1 start:1991 ScaleMinor = unit:year increment:5 start:1992
PlotData= Color:yellow mark:(line,black) align:left fontsize:M shift:(0,-3) # shift text to right side of bar
# there is no automatic collision detection, fontsize:XS # so shift texts up or down manually to avoid overlap shift:(25,-10)
at:2007 shift:15,-6 text: Airbus delivers first A380-800 at:2006 shift:15,-6 text: Certification and delays at:2005 shift:15,-6 text: Maiden flight at:2004 shift:15,-6 text: First engine delivered at:2002 shift:15,-6 text: Component-manufacturing starts at:2001 shift:15,-6 text: Airbus consortium is merged at:2000 shift:15,-6 text: Commercial launch of A3XX at:1996 shift:15,-6 text: ''Large Aircraft Division'' formed at:1993 shift:15,-6 text: Boeing cancels similar project at:1991 shift:15,-6 text: Market demand researched </timeline> </div> [[File:9M-MNF at Heathrow (12792743363).jpg|thumb|[[Airbus A380]], the largest passenger jet in the world, introduced in 2007.]] In mid-1988 a group of Airbus engineers led by Jean Roeder began working in secret on the development of an ultra-high-capacity airliner (UHCA), both to complete its own range of products and to break the dominance that [[Boeing]] had enjoyed in this market segment since the early 1970s with its [[Boeing 747|747]].<ref>Norris, 2005. p. 7.</ref> The project was announced at the 1990 [[Farnborough Air Show]], with the stated goal of 15% lower operating costs than the 747-400.<ref>Norris, 2005. p. 16-17.</ref> Airbus organised four teams of designers, one from each of its partners ([[AÃ©rospatiale]], [[DaimlerChrysler Aerospace]], [[British Aerospace]], [[EADS CASA|CASA]]) to propose new technologies for its future aircraft designs. In June 1994 Airbus began developing its own very large airliner, then designated as A3XX.<ref name = 'Beebover'/><ref>{{cite news | title = Airbus will reveal plan for super-jumbo: Aircraft would seat at least 600 people and cost dollars 8bn to develop |work=The Independent |location=UK | date = 4 June 1994 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/airbus-will-reveal-plan-for-superjumbo-aircraft-would-seat-at-least-600-people-and-cost-dollars-8bn-to-develop-1420367.html |first = David |last = Bowen }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Airbus unveils plans for 854-passenger airliner | website=The Baltimore Sun | date = 8 September 1994 | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/111882477.html?dids=111882477:111882477&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+08%2C+1994&author=&pub=The+Sun&desc=Airbus+unveils+plans+for+854-passenger+airliner&pqatl=google }}</ref> Airbus considered several designs, including an odd side-by-side combination of two fuselages from the Airbus A340, which was Airbus's largest jet at the time.<ref name="norris_wagner_book">{{cite book|last=Norris |first=Guy |author2=Mark Wagner |title=Airbus A380: Superjumbo of the 21st Century |publisher=Zenith Press |year=2005 |url=http://www.zenithpress.com/ProductDetails_32796.ncm |isbn=978-0-7603-2218-5 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507101924/http://www.zenithpress.com/ProductDetails_32796.ncm |archivedate=7 May 2009 }}</ref> Airbus refined its design, targeting a 15% to 20% reduction in operating costs over the existing Boeing 747â400. The A3XX design converged on a double-decker layout that provided more passenger volume than a traditional single-deck design.
Five A380s were built for testing and demonstration purposes.<ref name="flight_test_2005">{{cite news |title = A380 powers on through flight-test |last = Kingsley-Jones |first = Max | url = http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2005/12/20/203708/a380-powers-on-through-flight-test.html |publisher=[[Flight International]] |date = 20 December 2005 |accessdate =25 September 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070930043200/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2005/12/20/203708/a380-powers-on-through-flight-test.html| archivedate= 30 September 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> The first A380 was unveiled at a ceremony in Toulouse on 18 January 2005, and its maiden flight took place on 27 April 2005. After successfully landing three hours and 54 minutes later, chief test pilot [[Jacques Rosay]] said flying the A380 had been "like handling a bicycle".<ref name="First flight">{{cite web|title=A380 Successfully completes its first flight |publisher=Flug Revue |date=27 April 2005 |url=http://www.flug-revue.rotor.com/FRtypen/FRErstfl/FR05Erst/PRA380.htm |accessdate=14 March 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080417032419/http://www.flug-revue.rotor.com/FRtypen/FRErstfl/FR05Erst/PRA380.htm |archivedate=17 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> On 1 December 2005, the A380 achieved its maximum design speed of Mach 0.96.<ref name="flight_test_2005"/> On 10 January 2006, the A380 made its first transatlantic flight to [[MedellÃ­n]] in Colombia.<ref name="Cold wethet test">{{cite news | title = Airbus tests A380 jet in extreme cold of Canada | publisher=[[MSNBC]] | date = 8 February 2006 | url = http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/11236081/ | accessdate =16 September 2006 }}</ref>
The Airbus A380 was delayed in October 2006 due to the use of incompatible [[computer-aided design|software used to design]] the aircraft. Primarily, the [[Toulouse]] assembly plant used the latest version 5 of [[CATIA]] (made by [[Dassault]]), while the design centre at the [[Hamburg]] factory were using the older and incompatible version 4.<ref name="matlack2006">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2006-10-04/airbus-first-blame-the-software|title=Airbus: First, blame the Software|first=Carol|last=Matlack|work=Businessweek |date=5 October 2006|accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref> The result was that the 530 km of cables wiring throughout the aircraft had to be completely redesigned.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://manufacturing.cadalyst.com/manufacturing/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=390123|title=What Grounded the Airbus A380?|date=6 December 2006|first=Kenneth|last=Wong|publisher=Cadalyst|accessdate=12 December 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071130002721/http://manufacturing.cadalyst.com/manufacturing/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=390123| archivedate= 30 November 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Although no orders had been cancelled, Airbus still had to pay millions in late-delivery penalties.<ref name="matlack2006"/>
The first aircraft delivered was to [[Singapore Airlines]] on 15 October 2007 and entered service on 25 October 2007 with an inaugural flight between [[Singapore]] and Sydney.<ref name="1st SIA flight">{{cite news|title=First A380 Flight on 25â26 October  |url=http://www.a380.singaporeair.com/content/news/newsrelease/20070816/index.html |publisher=[[Singapore Airlines]] |date=16 August 2007 |accessdate=16 August 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195504/http://www.a380.singaporeair.com/content/news/newsrelease/20070816/index.html |archivedate=27 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= A380 superjumbo lands in Sydney |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7061164.stm |publisher=BBC |date=25 October 2007 |accessdate=22 October 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081205195536/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7061164.stm| archivedate= 5 December 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Two months later Singapore Airlines CEO Chew Choong Seng said that the A380 was performing better than both the airline and Airbus had anticipated, burning 20% less fuel per passenger than the airline's existing [[747-400]] fleet.<ref name="SIA's Chew: A380 pleases">{{cite news | title = SIA's Chew: A380 pleases, Virgin Atlantic disappoints | publisher=ATW Online | date = 13 December 2007 | url = http://atwonline.com/aircraftenginescomponents/news/sias-chew-a380-pleases-virgin-atlantic-disappoints-0309 | accessdate =4 September 2011 }}</ref> [[Emirates Airline|Emirates]] was the second airline to take delivery of the A380 on 28 July 2008 and started flights between [[Dubai]] and [[John F. Kennedy International Airport|New York]]<ref>{{cite news | title = Emirates A380 arrives in New York! | date = 3 August 2008 | accessdate =3 August 2008 | url =http://www.gadling.com/2008/08/03/emirates-a380-arrives-in-new-york/| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080904225503/http://www.gadling.com/2008/08/03/emirates-a380-arrives-in-new-york/| archivedate= 4 September 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> on 1 August 2008.<ref name="1st UAE flight">{{cite news | title = Emirates A380 Lands At New York's JFK | date = 1 August 2008 | accessdate =5 August 2008 | url = http://news.airwise.com/story/view/1217629915.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080806020526/http://news.airwise.com/story/view/1217629915.html| archivedate= 6 August 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Qantas]] followed on 19 September 2008, starting flights between Melbourne and Los Angeles on 20 October 2008.<ref name="1st QFA flight">{{cite news |title= Qantas A380 arrives in LA after maiden flight |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2008/10/21/1224351190665.html |work=The Age |location=Australia |date=21 October 2008 |accessdate=22 October 2008 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081023094057/http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2008/10/21/1224351190665.html| archivedate= 23 October 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Expansion and sale of BAE stake=== In 2003, Airbus and the Kaskol Group created an Airbus Engineering centre in Russia, which started with 30 engineers and since has emerged as a model of success for Airbusâ globalisation strategy. It was the first engineering facility to open in Europe outside the company's home countries. Equipped with state-of-the-art communications equipment and linked with Airbus engineering sites in France and Germany, the facility performs extensive work in disciplines such as fuselage structure, stress, system installation and design. In 2011, the centre employs some 200 engineers who have completed over 30 large-scale projects for the A320, the A330/A340 and the A380 programmes. Russian engineers also performed more than half of all design work on the A330-200F freighter, with its activity related to fuselage structure design, floor grids installation and junctions design. The centre currently is involved in the A320neo Sharklets design development and numerous design works for the A350 XWB programme.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.airbus.com/company/worldwide-presence/airbus-in-russia/|title=Airbus in Russia | Airbus, a leading aircraft manufacturer|publisher=Airbus.com|date=|accessdate=14 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130117014555/http://www.airbus.com/company/worldwide-presence/airbus-in-russia/#|archive-date=2013-01-17|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
On 6 April 2006 [[BAE Systems]] planned to sell its 20% share in Airbus, then "conservatively valued" at â¬3.5 billion (US$4.17 billion).<ref name="bbc_bae_20060406">{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4885426.stm |title = BAE Systems to sell Airbus stake |publisher=BBC News |date = 6 April 2006 | accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref> Analysts suggested the move to make partnerships with U.S. firms more feasible, in both financial and political terms.<ref name="wsj_bae_20060407">{{cite news |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB114439030968919877 |title = BAE in Talks With EADS to Sell its 20% Airbus Stake; British Firm is Focusing Increasingly on Defense Market, Especially in U.S. |author=Michaels, D. |work=The Wall Street Journal |date = 7 April 2006}}</ref> BAE originally sought to agree on a price with EADS through an informal process. Due to lengthy negotiations and disagreements over price, BAE exercised its [[put option]], which saw investment bank [[N M Rothschild & Sons|Rothschild]] appointed to give an independent valuation.
In June 2006 Airbus was embroiled in significant international controversy over an announcement of further delays in the delivery of its A380. Following the announcement the value of associated stock plunged by up to 25% in a matter of days, although it soon recovered afterwards. Allegations of [[insider trading]] on the part of [[NoÃ«l Forgeard]], CEO of EADS, its majority corporate parent, promptly followed. The loss of associated value was of grave concern to BAE, press described a "furious row" between BAE and EADS, with BAE believing the announcement was designed to depress the value of its share.<ref name="row">{{cite news |url = https://www.independent.co.uk/service/forum/article1014055.ece |title = BAE launches attack on EADS over Airbus superjumbo warning |work=The Independent |accessdate =4 September 2011 |first = Michael |last = Harrison | date=15 June 2006}}</ref> A French shareholder group filed a class action lawsuit against EADS for failing to inform investors of the financial implications of the A380 delays while airlines awaiting deliveries demanded compensation.<ref name="FT 20060711 frontpage">{{cite news |last=Hollinger |first=Peggy |author2=Done, Kevin |title=Sharp drop in orders at Airbus |pages=1, 14 |publisher=Financial Times Daily |date=11 July 2006 }}</ref> As a result, EADS chief [[NoÃ«l Forgeard]] and Airbus CEO [[Gustav Humbert]] resigned on 2 July 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/03/business/worldbusiness/03airbus.html |title = Top Officials of Airbus and EADS Step Down |work=The New York Times |date = 3 July 2006|first = Carter |last = Dougherty}}</ref>
On 2 July 2006 Rothschild valued BAE's stake at Â£1.9 billion (â¬2.75 billion), well below the expectation of BAE, analysts, and even EADS.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2006/jul/03/theairlineindustry.baesystemsbusiness |title = BAE under pressure to hold Airbus stake |work=The Guardian |date = 3 July 2006 |first = David |last = Gow |accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref> On 5 July BAE appointed independent auditors to investigate how the value of its share of Airbus had fallen from the original estimates to the Rothschild valuation; however in September 2006 BAE agreed to the sale of its stake in Airbus to EADS for Â£1.87 billion (â¬2.75 billion, $3.53 billion), pending BAE shareholder approval.<ref>{{cite news |title = BAE agrees to Â£1.87bn Airbus sale |publisher=BBC News |date = 6 September 2006 |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/5321626.stm | accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref> On 4 October shareholders voted in favour of the sale,<ref>{{cite news |last = Hotten |first = Russell |title = BAE vote clears sale of Airbus stake |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=UK |date = 4 October 2006 |url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2006/10/04/bcnbae04.xml }}</ref> leaving Airbus entirely owned by EADS.
==2008â2013==
On 29 February 2008, the [[United States Air Force]] awarded a $35 billion contract for aerial refueling tankers (the [[KC-45]]) to Northrop Grumman, with EADS as a major subcontractor. The contract, one of the largest created by the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defence]], is initially valued at $35 billion but has the potential to grow to $100 billion.
Under the contract, [[Northrop Grumman]] and EADS would build a fleet of 179 planes, based on the existing [[Airbus A330]], to provide in-air refueling to military aircraft, from fighter jets to cargo planes. While final assembly of the craft would take place at an Airbus plant near [[Mobile, Alabama]], parts would come from suppliers across the globe.<ref>{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/ousiv/idUSN2861183920080301 | title = Northrop-EADS beats Boeing to build U.S. tanker| accessdate=2008-03-01 |agency=Reuters | date=2008-03-01}}</ref>
However, the award was protested by [[Boeing]], the other bidder on the project, which was upheld by the [[GAO]]. In response to the new contest, on 8 March 2010, [[Northrop Grumman]] announced it was abandoning its bid for the new contract, with its CEO stating that the revised bid requirement favored Boeing.<ref>[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/northrop-abandons-bid-to-make-us-aerial-tankers-2010-03-08?reflink=MW_news_stmp "Northrop drops out of bid to make Air Force aerial tankers"], MarketWatch, 8 March 2010.</ref> On 20 April 2010, EADS announced it was re-entering the competition and intended to enter a bid with the KC-45.<ref>[http://www.kc45now.com/news-press-releases/04-20-2010.asp "EADS North America intends to submit proposal for U.S. Air Force tanker "] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131135925/http://www.kc45now.com/news-press-releases/04-20-2010.asp |date=31 January 2011 }}, EADS North America press release, 20 April 2010</ref>
EADS reported a 763 million euros loss for 2009 as a result of a 1.8 billion euros charge on the troubled [[Airbus A400M]] project and a 240 million euros charge related to the A380.<ref>'Airbus delays propel EADS to Â£691m loss' Daily Telegraph, 10 March 2010</ref>
On 12 September 2012 it was reported<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2012/09/12/eads-et-bae-systems-negocient-une-possible-fusion_1759290_3234.html#ens_id=1741114&xtor=RSS-3208 |title=La fusion EADS-BAE Systems sous la pression du code boursier britannique |publisher=Lemonde.fr |date=2012-09-13 |accessdate=2013-06-20}}</ref> that [[BAE]] and EADS were in discussions regarding a possible merger. In the event of the merger, BAE shareholders would own 40 % and EADS 60 % of the new enlarged organisation.<ref name=BBC092012->{{cite news|title=BAE Systems shares shed gains after EADS merger talk|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-19584078|accessdate=13 September 2012|publisher=BBC|date=13 September 2012}}</ref><ref name=Bloomberg092012>{{cite news|title=Boeing Says EADS Seeking U.S. Growth With BAE Merger|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-09-13/boeing-says-eads-seeking-u-s-growth-with-bae-merger.html|publisher=Bloomberg|date=13 September 2012}}</ref> A key French EADS shareholder [[LagardÃ¨re Group|Lagardere]] asked EADS to rethink the proposed merger plan as the conditions were unsatisfactory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lagardere asks EADS to rethink BAE merger plan|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2012/10/01/uk-lagardere-eads-bae-idUKBRE89005820121001|accessdate=1 October 2012|newspaper=Reuters|date=1 October 2012}}</ref> The bosses of BAE Systems and EADS issued a joint statement seeking political support for their proposed 35 billion euro (US$45 billion) merger from the British, French and German governments; and reiterated that the combination is borne out of opportunity, not necessity and the new company would be greater than the sum of its parts.<ref>{{cite news|title=BAE and EADS chiefs: 'Time to create something stronger|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/industry/9577795/BAE-and-EADS-chiefs-Time-to-create-something-stronger.html|accessdate=1 October 2012|newspaper=Telegraph|date=30 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BAE and EADS bosses plead for support for merger|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2012/oct/01/bae-eads-merger-appeal?newsfeed=true|accessdate=1 October 2012|newspaper=Guardian|date=1 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=EADS and BAE: Bosses urge political support for merger|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-19781941|accessdate=1 October 2012|newspaper=BBC|date=1 October 2012}}</ref> It was reported on 10 October 2012, that the merger between BAE Systems and EADS had been called off.<ref>{{cite news|title=BAE-EADS merger cancelled amid political impasse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-19897699|accessdate=10 October 2012|newspaper=BBC|date=10 October 2012}}</ref>
==From EADS NV to Airbus SE==
In January 2014, EADS was reorganised as ''Airbus Group NV'', with three divisions (Airbus, [[Airbus Defence and Space]], and [[Airbus Helicopters]].<ref name=ft20140102/><ref>[http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/9e29cfb0-73be-11e3-a0c0-00144feabdc0.html#axzz2pGiV3qzr EADS changes name to Airbus], subscription required</ref><ref name="bbc.co.uk">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-23513650 BBC News - EADS to be renamed Airbus Group]. Bbc.co.uk (2013-07-31). Retrieved on 2013-08-16.</ref> On 27 May 2015 the company became a ''[[Societas Europaea]]'' (SE) (Latin: European Company), having been a ''[[Naamloze vennootschap]]'' ([[public company|public]] [[limited liability company|limited]] company).<ref name="Airbus Group SE"/> In September 2016, Airbus Group announced that it would merge with its largest division, Airbus SAS, into a new entity and introduce a single Airbus brand,<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2016/09/Ad-hoc-release--Airbus-Steps-Up-Integration.html|title=Ad-hoc release, 30 September 2016: Airbus Steps Up Integration|publisher=Airbus Group|date=30 September 2016|accessdate=30 September 2016}}</ref> the merge to take effect on 1 January 2017.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2016/11/Airbus-becomes-One.html|title=Airbus Becomes One: Next Steps in the Social Dialogue|publisher=Airbus Group|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=29 November 2016}}</ref> The group reorganized under the brand name of "Airbus" in January 2017. The subsidiaries Airbus Helicopters and Airbus Defence and Space became operating divisions of the same company.<ref>{{cite news|title=Airbus Plans Internal Merger in Latest Corporate Shake-Up|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/30/airbus-group-merger/|accessdate=21 January 2017|agency=Reuters|publisher=Fortune|date=Sep 30, 2016}}</ref> Airbus Group SE changed its legal name to ''Airbus SE'' at its 2017 annual meeting on 12 April 2017.<ref name="Airbus SE"/>
===2007 restructuring of Airbus SAS=== On 9 October 2006 [[Christian Streiff]], Humbert's successor, resigned due to differences with parent company EADS over the amount of independence he would be granted in implementing his reorganisation plan for Airbus.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6035357.stm |publisher=BBC News |title=Streiff resigns as CEO of Airbus |date=9 October 2006 | accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref> He was succeeded by EADS co-CEO [[Louis Gallois]], bringing Airbus under more direct control of its parent company.
On 28 February 2007, CEO Louis Gallois announced the company's restructuring plans. Entitled Power<sup>8</sup>, the plan would see 10,000 jobs cut over four years; 4,300 in France, 3,700 in Germany, 1,600 in the UK and 400 in Spain. 5,000 of the 10,000 would be at [[subcontractor]]s. Plants at [[Saint Nazaire]], [[Varel]] and [[Laupheim]] face sell off or closure, while [[Meaulte]], [[Nordenham]] and [[Filton]] are "open to investors".<ref>{{cite news |title= Airbus confirms 10,000 job cuts|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6402859.stm|publisher=BBC News |date= 28 February 2007 | accessdate=4 September 2011}}</ref> As of 16 September 2008 the Laupheim plant has been sold to a Thales-Diehl consortium to form [[Diehl Aerospace]] and while the design activities at Filton have been retained, the manufacturing operations have been sold to British company [[GKN]].<ref>{{cite news |title = GKN buys Airbus operation in the U.K. |url = http://defensenews.com/story.php?i=3724705&c=EUR&s=TOP |publisher = Defence News |date = 15 September 2008 |first = Andrew |last = Chuter }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The announcements resulted in Airbus unions in France and Germany threatening strike action.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/world/20070302-0438-france-airbus.html |title = Airbus unions call for a strike on Tuesday over job cuts |publisher=SignOnSanDiego |date = 2 March 2007 |first = Laurence |last = Frost}}</ref>
===2011 A320neo record orders=== At the 2011 [[Paris Air Show]], Airbus received total orders valued at about $72.2 billion for 730 aircraft, representing a new record in the civil aviation industry. The [[A320neo]] ("new engine option") model, announced in December 2010, received 667 orders; this, together with previous orders, resulted in a total of 1029 orders within six months of launch date, creating another industry record.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.auairs.com/html/99784_I.-The-Paris-Air-Show-Airbus-730-orders-worth-$-72-billion.html |title=I. The Paris Air Show, Airbus 730 orders worth $ 72 billion |publisher=Auairs.com |date= |accessdate=14 January 2013 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
===2016 deal with Iran=== In January 2016 Airbus announced it has signed a tentative agreement with [[Iran]] to sell 118 Airbus aircraft along with a comprehensive civil aviation cooperation package as a part of the implementation of the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]] (JCPOA).<ref>{{cite press release |url = http://www.airbus.com/presscentre/pressreleases/press-release-detail/detail/iran-deal/ |publisher = Airbus |title = Iran selects Airbus for its civil aviation renewal |date = 28 January 2016 |access-date = 2018-05-05 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160709172813/http://www.airbus.com/presscentre/pressreleases/press-release-detail/detail/iran-deal/# |archive-date = 2016-07-09 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> Boeing has also announced its will to sell 80 jets directly to Iran Air as part of a proposed deal worth up to $17.6bn.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/proposed-boeing-iran-air-deal-involves-80-jets-1466701529/ |website=The Wall Street Journal |title= Proposed Boeing-Iran Air Deal Involves 80 Jets |date= June 23, 2016}}</ref>
However, In early July 2016, [[US House of Representatives]] passed amendments that would block [[US Department of Treasury]] funds from granting [[export]] licences or reexport of passenger commercial aircraft. Boeing reacted that if its deal with Iran is blocked by the [[US Congress]], all other companies that supply to its rivals should be prohibited as well. Airbus, too, has said that it requires US's approval to export airliners to Iran, because parts of its aircraft are made in the US.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/boeing-says-if-congress-blocks-its-iran-jet-deal-rivals-should-be-halted-too-1468167871/ |website=The Wall Street Journal |title =Boeing Says If Congress Blocks Its Iran Jet Deal, Rivalsâ Should Be Halted Too |date= July 10, 2016}}</ref>
The deal between Iran Air and Airbus was finally implemented, and the first new purchased Airbus aircraft, an A321, landed in Tehran's International [[Mehr Abad Airport]] on January 12, 2017; Airbus stated that the delivery has been in full compliance with the JCPOA and US government [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] licenses.<ref name=170111PR>{{cite press release |url= http://www.airbus.com/presscentre/pressreleases/press-release-detail/detail/iran-air-takes-delivery-of-its-first-of-100-airbus-aircraft/ |publisher= Airbus |title= Iran Air takes delivery of its first of 100 Airbus aircraft |date= 11 January 2017}}</ref>
===2017=== On 30 June, Airbus said its airliner sales team would now report directly to [[Tom Enders]] and by-pass [[Fabrice Bregier]], which will lead programs, support and services, engineering, manufacturing, procurement and quality while Enders will lead sales and marketing.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-airbus-reorganisation-idUSKBN19O0HW |date= Jul 3, 2017 |title= Airbus unveils leaner structure and sales shake-up |author= Tim Hepher and Sudip Kar-Gupta |work= Reuters}}</ref>
On 16 October, Airbus and [[Bombardier Aerospace]] announced a partnership on the [[CSeries]] program, with Airbus acquiring a 50.01% majority stake, Bombardier keeping 31% and [[Investissement QuÃ©bec]] 19%, to expand in an estimated market of more than 6,000 new 100-150 seat aircraft over 20 years; Airbusâ [[supply chain]] expertise should save production costs but headquarters and [[Assembly line|assembly]] remain in QuÃ©bec while U.S. customers would benefit from a second Final Assembly Line in [[Mobile, Alabama]].<ref name=Airbus16oct2017>{{cite press release |url= http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2017/10/airbus-bombardier-cseries-agreement.html |title= Airbus and Bombardier Announce C Series Partnership |publisher= Airbus |date= 16 October 2017}}</ref>
In the fall, [[Der Spiegel]] investigated systematic corruption and improper intermediates usage in past sales and questioned whether Enders can survive the scandal as he did not react quickly enough, then [[Handelsblatt]] reported the French government wants to control Airbus again and Bregier wants to get Enders fired to gain his position.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://aviationweek.com/commercial-aviation/intrigue-shakespearean-proportions-unfolds-airbus-top-echelon |title= Intrigue Of Shakespearean Proportions Unfolds In Airbusâ Top Echelon |date= Nov 9, 2017 |author= Jens Flottau |work= Aviation Week & Space Technology}}</ref>
Sales chief [[John Leahy (executive)|John Leahy]] was supposed to retire at the end of 2017 to be replaced by his deputy Kiran Rao.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-airbus-leahy/leahy-to-bow-out-from-airbus-at-year-end-after-final-sales-push-idUSKBN1CG1QE |date= Oct 11, 2017 |title= Leahy to bow out from Airbus at year-end after final sales push |author= Tim Hepher |agency= Reuters}}</ref> A few weeks before the switch, Rao told Airbus CEO Tom Enders that he was no longer available.<!--<ref name=AvWeek23nov2017>--> After investigations into alleged [[bribery]], Enders is taking personal responsibility for the sales organization compliance.<!--<ref name=AvWeek23nov2017>--> Leahy should stay till a successor is found, maybe Frenchmen Eric Schulz, [[aerospace engineer]] and president of [[Rolls-Royce plc]] Civil Aerospace or Christian Scherer, CEO of [[ATR Aircraft]], [[strategist]] and [[salesman]].<ref name=AvWeek23nov2017>{{cite news |url= http://aviationweek.com/commercial-aviation/rolls-royce-s-schulz-atr-s-scherer-contenders-airbus-sales-chief |title= Rolls-Royceâs Schulz, ATRâs Scherer Contenders For Airbus Sales Chief |date= Nov 23, 2017 |author= Jens Flottau |work= Aviation Week & Space Technology}}</ref> Schulz should replace Leahy on 25 January.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-airbus-appointment-exclusive/exclusive-airbus-set-to-poach-rolls-exec-to-head-jetliner-sales-sources-idUSKBN1DQ0GR |title= Airbus set to poach Rolls exec to head jetliner sales - sources |date= Nov 26, 2017 |author= Tim Hepher |agency= Reuters}}</ref>
In November, Paul Eremenko, Airbus's CTO, quit after two years. French unions held him for responsible for the job cuts made at a French research facility nearby Paris. Tom Enders, Airbus chief executive, was counting on Paul Eremenko to create a radically different approach to R&D.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-airbus-management/airbus-technology-head-eremenko-leaves-to-join-rival-utc-idUSKBN1DU1H3 |title= Airbus technology head Eremenko leaves to join rival UTC |date= Nov 30, 2017 |author= Tim Hepher |agency= Reuters}}</ref>
On 28 November 2017, Airbus announced a partnership with [[Rolls-Royce plc]] and [[Siemens]] to develop the [[E-Fan X]] hybrid-[[electric aircraft]] demonstrator, to fly in 2020.<ref name=28nov2017PR>{{cite press release |url= https://www.siemens.com/press//pool/de/pressemitteilungen/2017/corporate/PR2017110098COEN.pdf |title= Airbus, Rolls-Royce, and Siemens team up for electric future |date= 28 Nov 2017 |publisher= Airbus, Rolls-Royce, Siemens }} ([http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2017/11/airbus--rolls-royce--and-siemens-team-up-for-electric-future-par.html Airbus], [https://www.rolls-royce.com/media/press-releases/yr-2017/28-11-2017-airbus-rr-and-siemens-team-up-for-electric-future.aspx Rolls-Royce], [https://www.siemens.com/press/PR2017110098COEN Siemens])</ref>
Enders CEO mandate runs until April 2019 and his reconduction is decided by Airbus' board, but in December he said would not seek a third mandate while he was in April as he is pressured over corruption investigations.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-airbus-enders/airbus-ceo-enders-declines-comment-on-role-beyond-2019-idUKKBN1E62OG |date= Dec 12, 2017 |title= Airbus CEO Enders declines comment on role beyond 2019 |agency= Reuters |author= Dominique Vidalon and Tim Hepher }}</ref> On 15 December, the Board confirmed Enders will not stay beyond April 2019 and announced that in February 2018 BrÃ©gier will be replaced by [[Guillaume Faury]], currently [[Airbus Helicopters]] CEO.<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2017/12/succession-planning.html |title= Airbus Board of Directors Announces Top Management Succession Plan |publisher= Airbus |date= 15 December 2017}}</ref><!-- media coverage: https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/airbuss-bregier-to-step-down-enders-not-seeking-ce-444219/ https://www.reuters.com/article/us-airbus-management/airbus-confirms-management-shake-up-idUSKBN1E90F8 --> The renewal should have been disclosed in early 2018, the media hype accelerated its timing but not the decision.<!--<ref name=AvWeek18dec2017>--> When told by the board that he would not succeed Enders as CEO, Bregier chose to leave.<!--<ref name=AvWeek18dec2017>--> Besides Enders, Bregier, Leahy and Eremenko, engineering chief [[Charles Champion]] is retiring at the end of 2017, [[Airbus North America]] chairman [[Allan McArtor]] is leaving, as is the unit's CEO Barry Eccleston to be replaced by Jeff Knittel, CEO of lessor [[CIT Aerospace]].<!--<ref name=AvWeek18dec2017>--> Head of military aircraft [[Fernando Alonso (engineer)|Fernando Alonso]], civil aircraft division COO Tom Williams and head of programs Didier Evrard are also nearing retirement.<ref name=AvWeek18dec2017>{{cite news |url= http://aviationweek.com/commercial-aviation/airbus-facing-leadership-changes-amid-turmoil-corruption-probes |title= Airbus Facing Leadership Changes Amid Turmoil, Corruption Probes |date= Dec 18, 2017 |author= Jens Flottau and Tony Osborne |work= Aviation Week & Space Technology}}</ref>
For 2017, Airbus announced it received 1,109 net orders from 44 customers in 2017, and delivered 718 aircraft to 85 customers: 558 A320 Family (including 181 A320neo); 67 A330s; 78 A350 XWBs and 15 A380s.<ref name=Airbus15jan2018>{{cite press release |url= http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2018/01/airbus-commercial-aircraft-delivers-record-performance.html |title= Airbus Commercial Aircraft delivers record performance |publisher= Airbus }}</ref>
===2018=== As the [[UK leaves the EU]], Airbus has been approached by at least seven governments (France, Germany, Spain, U.S., China, Mexico and South Korea) for [[wing]] production [[competitiveness]].<!--<ref name=Bloomberg30jan2018>--> Currently produced in [[Broughton, Flintshire|Broughton]] and designed in [[Filton]] since 1970, wing production employs 15,000 people, which is over 10% of Airbus staff.<!--<ref name=Bloomberg30jan2018>--> [[carbon composite|Composite]] wings will be needed to lower fuel burn by 30% for the [[A320]] replacement.<ref name=Bloomberg30jan2018>{{cite news |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-30/brexit-exposes-u-k-to-worldwide-raid-on-airbus-wing-production |title= Brexit Exposes U.K. to Worldwide Raid on Airbus Wing Production |author= Benjamin D Katz |date= 30 Jan 2018 |agency= Bloomberg}}</ref> Tom Enders later promised the U.K. government Business Secretary [[Greg Clark]] that Airbus would retain its British operations âlong into the futureââ and see the U.K. as a âhome country and a competitive place to invest.ââ <ref name=Bloomberg22feb2018>{{cite news |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-22/airbus-ceo-vows-to-stay-in-post-brexit-u-k-for-a-very-long-time |title= Airbus CEO Vows to Stay in Post-Brexit U.K. Long Into Future |date= 22 Feb 2018 |author= Alex Morales and Benjamin D Katz |agency= Bloomberg}}</ref> Airbus will designate a new CEO to succeed Enders by the end of 2018, which will be submitted to shareholders at the spring 2019 annual meeting, with planemaking boss and former Eurocopter head [[Guillaume Faury]] as the main internal candidate.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-airbus-ceo/airbus-to-name-new-ceo-at-the-end-of-the-year-idUSKBN1GW2JX |date= March 20, 2018 |title= Airbus to name new CEO at the end of the year |author= Tim Hepher, Cyril Altmeyer |agency= Reuters}}</ref> Airbus chief financial officer [[Harald Wilhelm]] will quit when Enders will leave in 2019.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/airbus-finance-chief-wilhelm-joins-management-exodus-448558/ |title= Airbus finance chief Wilhelm joins management exodus |date= 14 May 2018 |author= David Kaminski-Morrow |work= Flightglobal}}</ref>
On 15 May, in its [[Competition_between_Airbus_and_Boeing#World_Trade_Organization_litigation|EU appeal ruling]], the WTO concluded that the [[A380]] and [[A350]] received improper [[subsidies]] through repayable launch aids or low [[interest rate]]s which could have been avoided, and Airbus agreed to correct those [[Violation of law|violation]]s.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/airbus-confirms-a380-and-a350-launch-aid-amendments-448786/ |title= Airbus confirms A380 and A350 launch-aid amendments |date= 22 May 2018 |author= David Kaminski-Morrow |work= Flightglobal}}</ref>
On 13 September, [[Eric Schulz]] left the Chief Commercial Officer role for personal reasons and was replaced by [[Christian Scherer]], CEO of [[ATR (aircraft manufacturer)|ATR]] since October 2016.<ref>{{cite press release |url= https://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2018/09/christian-scherer-appointed-airbus-chief-commercial-officer.html |date= 13 September 2018 |title= Commercial Aircraft Christian Scherer appointed Airbus Chief Commercial Officer |publisher= Airbus}}</ref> As Schulz was previously head of [[Rolls-Royce plc]] civil engines, currently suffering problems, airlines could had a skewed opinion.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-airbus-moves-exclusive/airbus-appoints-atr-boss-as-sales-chief-after-schulz-quits-idUKKCN1LT2GA |title= Company veteran named Airbus sales chief after ex-Rolls executive quits |author= Tim Hepher |date= 13 September 2018 |agency= Reuters}}</ref>
On 8 October, the Board of directors selected Guillaume Faury to succeed Tom Enders as Airbus CEO from 10 April 2019.<ref>{{cite press release |url= https://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2018/10/airbus-board-of-directors-selects-guillaume-faury-future-chief-e.html |title= Airbus Board of Directors Selects Guillaume Faury Future Chief Executive Officer |date= 8 October 2018 |publisher= Airbus}}</ref> On 21 November, Airbus appointed [[Michael SchÃ¶llhorn]], COO for [[BSH Home Appliances]] GmbH, to succeed [[Tom Williams (executive)|Tom Williams]] as Chief Operating Officer (COO) for Airbus Commercial Aircraft from 1 February 2019,<ref>{{cite press release |url= https://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2018/11/airbus-appoints-michael-schoellhorn-as-chief-operating-officer-.html |date= 21 November 2018 |title= Company Airbus appoints Michael SchÃ¶llhorn as Chief Operating Officer |publisher= Airbus}}</ref> and [[Dominik Asam]], CFO of [[Infineon Technologies]], to succeed Harald Wilhelm as Chief Financial Officer from 10 April 2019.<ref>{{cite press release |url= https://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2018/11/airbus-selects-dominik-asam-as-future-chief-financial-officer-.html |date= 21 November 2018 |title= Company Airbus selects Dominik Asam as future Chief Financial Officer |publisher= Airbus}}</ref>
==Competition with Boeing== {{Main|Competition between Airbus and Boeing}} {{Orders and deliveries of Airbus and Boeing}} Airbus is in tight competition with Boeing every year for aircraft orders although Airbus has secured over 50% of aircraft orders in the decade since 2003.<ref name=AirbusO&D>{{cite web|title=Airbus April 2013 orders and deliveries|url=http://www.airbus.com/no_cache/company/market/orders-deliveries/|publisher=Airbus|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref>
Airbus won a greater share of orders in 2003 and 2004. In 2005, Airbus achieved 1111 (1055 net) orders,<ref name="airbuspageorders">{{cite web|url=http://www.airbus.com/en/corporate/orders_and_deliveries/ |title=Airbus Orders and Deliveries |publisher=Airbus |accessdate=30 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907084244/http://www.airbus.com/en/corporate/orders_and_deliveries/ |archivedate=7 September 2009 }}</ref> compared to 1029 (net of 1002) for the same year at rival Boeing<ref>{{cite web|url=http://active.boeing.com/commercial/orders/index.cfm?content=displaystandardreport.cfm&optReportType=AnnOrd&pageid=m15521|accessdate=30 September 2009|title=Orders and Deliveries |publisher=Boeing}}</ref> However, Boeing won 55% of 2005 orders proportioned by value; and in the following year Boeing won more orders by both measures. Airbus in 2006 achieved its second best year ever in its entire 35-year history in terms of the number of orders it received, 824, second only to the previous year.<ref name="airbus2006res">{{cite web|url=http://www.airbus.com/store/mm_repository/pdf/att00008917/media_object_file_Airbus2006AnnualReview.pdf |accessdate=7 October 2009 |title=Airbus Annual Review 2006 |publisher=Airbus |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408020435/http://www.airbus.com/store/mm_repository/pdf/att00008917/media_object_file_Airbus2006AnnualReview.pdf |archivedate=8 April 2009 }}</ref> Airbus plans to increase production of [[Airbus A320|A320]] airliners to reach 40 per month by 2012, at a time when Boeing is increasing monthly 737 production from 31.5 to 35 per month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/08/10/345959/airbus-ups-stakes-in-single-aisle-production-war.html |accessdate=16 August 2010 |title=Airbus ups stakes in single-aisle production war | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100817184040/http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/08/10/345959/airbus-ups-stakes-in-single-aisle-production-war.html| archivedate= 17 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
Regarding operational aircraft, there were 7,264 Airbus aircraft operational at April 2013.<ref name="AirbusO&D"/> Although Airbus secured over 50% of aircraft orders in the decade since 2003, the number of Boeing aircraft still in operation at April 2013 still exceeded Airbus by 21% because Airbus made a late entry into the market, 1972 vs. 1958 for Boeing; this lead is diminishing as older aircraft are progressively retired.
Though both manufacturers have a broad product range in various segments from [[Narrow-body aircraft|single-aisle]] to [[wide-body aircraft|wide-body]], their aircraft do not always compete head-to-head. Instead they respond with models slightly smaller or bigger than the other in order to plug any holes in demand and achieve a better edge. The A380, for example, is designed to be larger than the 747. The A350XWB competes with the high end of the 787 and the low end of the 777. The A320 is bigger than the 737-700 but smaller than the 737â800. The A321 is bigger than the 737â900 but smaller than the previous 757-200. Airlines see this as a benefit since they get a more complete product range, from 100 seats to 500 seats, than if both companies offered identical aircraft.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/tedreed/2014/05/25/at-american-airlines-airbus-a321-is-forcing-out-the-a320/#5f9fdae642e9|title=At American Airlines, Airbus A321 Is Forcing Out the A320|last=Reed|first=Ted|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:A350 First Flight - Low pass 02.jpg|thumb|The first [[Airbus A350|Airbus A350 XWB]] on its maiden flight.]] In recent years the [[Boeing 777]] has outsold its Airbus counterparts, which include the A340 family as well as the A330-300. The smaller A330-200 competes with the [[Boeing 767|767]], outselling its Boeing counterpart in recent years. The A380 is anticipated to further reduce sales of the Boeing 747, gaining Airbus a share of the market in very large aircraft, though frequent delays in the A380 programme have caused several customers to consider the refreshed [[Boeing 747-8|747â8]].<ref name="times_delays_20061004">{{cite news|url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,9077-2387999,00.html|title=Airbus will lose â¬4.8bn because of A380 delays|first=David|last=Robertson|work=The Times |location=UK |date=4 October 2006 }}</ref> Airbus has also proposed the [[Airbus A350 XWB|A350 XWB]] to compete with the [[Boeing 787 Dreamliner]], after being under great pressure from airlines to produce a competing model.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/landingpage/airbus%20a350.html |title=Aircraft Profile: Airbus A350 |publisher=Flight International |accessdate=1 October 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091022000154/http://www.flightglobal.com/landingpage/airbus%2Ba350.html |archivedate=22 October 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.leeham.net/filelib/ScottsColumn040406.pdf |title=Redesigning the A350: Airbusâ tough choice |publisher=Leeham Company |date=4 April 2006 |first=Scott |last=Hamilton |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327094646/http://www.leeham.net/filelib/ScottsColumn040406.pdf |archivedate=27 March 2009 }}</ref>
== AÂ³ == In 2015, Airbus Group said it was establishing an R&D center and venture capital fund in Silicon Valley.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2015/05/20150529_airbus_group_silicon_valley.html|title=Airbus Group Establishes Venture Capital Fund and Innovation Center in Silicon Valley|publisher=Airbus Group|date=29 May 2015|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/29/airbus-group-idUSL5N0YK4XF20150529|title=Airbus Group starts $150 mln venture fund, Silicon Valley base|publisher=Reuters|date=29 May 2015|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> Airbus CEO Fabrice Bregier stated: "What is the weakness of a big group like Airbus when we talk about innovation? We believe that we have better ideas than the rest of the world. We believe that we know because we control the technologies and platforms. The world has shown us in the car industry, the space industry and the hi-tech industry that this is not true. And we need to be open to others' ideas and others' innovations,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/articleshow/47507116.cms|title=In a first, Bengaluru startups on Airbus radar for mentoring business ideas under BizLabs|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>
Airbus Group CEO [[Tom Enders]] stated that "The only way to do it for big companies is really to create spaces outside of the main business where we allow and where we incentivize experimentation... That is what we have started to do but there is no manual... It is a little bit of trial and error. We all feel challenged by what the Internet companies are doing."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ahles|first1=Andrea|title=A Q&A with Airbus CEO Tom Enders|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/news/business/aviation/sky-talk-blog/article25185454.html|accessdate=25 June 2015|work=Star-Telegram|date=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
Six months after launch, the Airbus Group Venture fund in Silicon Valley became fully operational in January 2016.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.airbus.com/newsroom/press-releases/en/2016/01/20160117_airbus_group_silicon_valley.html|title=Airbus Group Becomes Fully Operational in Silicon Valley|publisher=Airbus Group|date=16 January 2016|accessdate=23 January 2016}}</ref>
==Historical emblems== Emblems of Airbus Industrie GIE (1970â2000) and Airbus SAS (2001â2016), until the latter on 1 January 2017 merged with its parent company, Airbus Group SE:
Emblems of the European Aeronautic Defence and Space Company NV (2000â2014), Airbus Group NV (2014â2015) and Airbus Group SE (2015â2017): <gallery widths="180px" heights="80px">

</gallery>

Trade Relations|publisher=St. Martin's Press|year=1997}} *{{cite book|last=McIntyre|first=Ian|title=Dogfight: The Transatlantic Battle Over Airbus|publisher=Praeger Publishers|year=1982|isbn=0-275-94278-3}} *{{cite book|last=Thornton|first=David Weldon|title=Airbus Industrie: The Politics of an International Industrial Collaboration |publisher=St. Martin's Press|year=1995|isbn=0-312-12441-4}}

{{Infobox company | name = Hitit Computer Services | type = Private | foundation = 1994 | location = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | key_people = Nur Gokman ([[Chief Executive Officer]]), Dilek Ovacik ([[Chief Financial Officer]]), Ayse Erinc ([[Chief Strategy Officer]]), Aysu Demirtel ([[Chief Operations Officer]]), Mert Gulcur (Head Of Technology and Delivery) | industry = [[Travel technology]] | services = Passenger Service Systems; Commercial IT systems for the travel industry }} '''Hitit Computer Services''' is a [[private company]] that sells commercial IT systems for the [[travel industry]]. Its headquarters is in the [[ITU ArÄ± Technopolis]] science park on the campus of [[Istanbul Technical University]].
Hitit was established as an IT company by executives from Turkish Airlines in 1994.<ref name= Erdinc>{{cite journal| last= Erdinc | first= Ersun|title= Suya Konan Turna |journal= Forbes Turkiye | date=August 2012 | pages= 104â105}}</ref> The first program sold by the company was Crane FF which became the most common loyalty management system, by number of airline users.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eglobaltravelmedia.com.au/amadeus-enters-airline-customer-loyalty-arena-with-acquisition-of-hitit-loyalty/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140414050032/http://www.eglobaltravelmedia.com.au/amadeus-enters-airline-customer-loyalty-arena-with-acquisition-of-hitit-loyalty/ |archivedate=2014-04-14 |df= }}</ref> Hitit introduced its new generation [[airline reservations system]] in 2004. The company opened an office in Dubai due to an increasing number of airline customers in the Middle East. Hitit is one of Turkeyâs biggest software exporters: with 83% of its customerbase being overseas and 92% of its revenues coming from exports,around $5million-8$million revenue, it became the 3rd largest service exporter of 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.akbank.com.tr/kobi/dis-ticaret/ihracatin-yildizlari/Sayfalar/2011-odulleri.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141010213621/https://www.akbank.com.tr/kobi/dis-ticaret/ihracatin-yildizlari/Sayfalar/2011-odulleri.aspx |archivedate=2014-10-10 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maxihaber.net/fotolar/2012_foto/haziran_2012/mh_hitit_bilgisayar_02062012.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140414130354/http://www.maxihaber.net/fotolar/2012_foto/haziran_2012/mh_hitit_bilgisayar_02062012.htm |archivedate=2014-04-14 |df= }}</ref>
The company had two divisions until 8 April 2014 when the Loyalty Division of Hitit was acquired by the [[Amadeus IT Group]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnooz.com/article/amadeus-acquires-hitit-loyalty/|title=Amadeus acquires Hitit Loyalty|website=Tnooz.com|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> The Airline Division of Hitit remains independent and continues to sell software to airlines and travel companies from Europe, Middle East, Africa and Asia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hititcs.com/about-us/|title=Hitit Computer Services - Airline IT Solutions|website=Hititcs.com|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> With 318% growth rate{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}, the company was in Deloitte's Technology Fast 500 EMEA list in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/global/en/pages/technology-media-and-telecommunications/articles/Technology-Fast-500-EMEA-2013-Winners.html|title=Technology Fast 500â¢ EMEA Winners - Deloitte Global - Technology, Media and Telecommunication|website=Deloitte|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> and it is also an International Air Transport Association Strategic Partner.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.iata.org/about/sp/Pages/partners.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413134742/https://www.iata.org/about/sp/Pages/partners.aspx |archivedate=2014-04-13 |df= }}</ref> Today, the company sells products covering a range from passenger service systems to financial, operational and loyalty management systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.terrapinn.com/conference/world-low-cost-airlines/exhibitor-hitit-computer-services.stm|title=New routes, new revenues, new business models - Aviation Festival 2017|date=9 August 2017|website=Terrapinn.com|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/hitit-sirketler-grubu-amadeus-ile-anlasti-sektorel-1691294/|title=Hitit Åirketler Grubu Amadeus ile anlaÅtÄ±|first=milliyet.com.tr TÃ¼rkiye'nin lider haber|last=sitesi|website=Milliyet.com.tr|accessdate=9 August 2017}}</ref> Recently, Pakistan International Airlines (PIAC) has acquired the services provided by HITIT in a step to solve the issues it previously encountered by using SABRE system.
==See also== * [[Sabre (computer system)|Sabre]] * [[Navitaire]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Housing and Building Research Institute |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 2016 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = Bangladesh |members = |language = Bengali |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.hbri.gov.bd Housing and Building Research Institute] |remarks = }} '''Housing and Building Research Institute (HBRI)''' is an [[autonomous]] organization under [[Government of Bangladesh]] Ministry of Housing and Public Works.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/city/inception-workshop-promoting-sustainable-building-held-capital-1261264|title=Inception workshop on promoting sustainable building held in capital|date=2016-07-29|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-15|language=en}}</ref>
== History == The institute was established through the passing of the Housing and Building Research Institutes Act 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/country/govt-okays-3-draft-laws-1339168|title=Govt okays 3 draft laws|date=2017-01-02|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-15|language=en}}</ref>
==Institutional structure== The Institute has a total of 153 personnel including 33 qualified research personnel. All activities including [[R & D]] programme are now being executed through the following Divisions and Sections:
===Divisions=== * Software Engineer * Building Materials Division * Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering Division * Housing Division
===Sections=== * Extension and Dissemination Wing * Information and Documentation Section * Administrative & Accounts Section * Training Cell
==References== {{Reflist}}
