[[Image:Eisenwasserstoffw.jpg|thumb|right|Ironâhydrogen resistor for 2 to 6 Volt / 0.1 Ampere]] [[Image:Bareters 085b55 12.jpg|thumb|right|Ironâhydrogen resistor (barretter)]] An '''ironâhydrogen resistor''' consists of a [[hydrogen]]-filled glass bulb (similar to a light bulb), in which an [[iron]] wire is located. This resistor has a [[positive temperature coefficient]] of resistance. This characteristic made it useful for stabilizing circuits against fluctuations in power supply voltages.<ref>[http://www.vintage-radio.com/repair-restore-information/valve_power-supply-stages.html Power Supply Stages]</ref> This device is often called a "barretter" because of its similarity to the [[Hot wire barretter|barretter]] used for detection of radio signals. The modern successor to the ironâhydrogen resistor is the [[current source]].
==Operation== When the current increases the temperature will increase. The higher temperature leads to a higher [[electrical resistance]], opposing the increase in current. The hydrogen gas protects the iron against [[oxidation]], and also enhances the effect since the solubility of hydrogen in iron increases as temperature increases, resulting in higher resistance.
==Uses== Ironâhydrogen resistors were used in the early [[vacuum tube]] systems in series with the tube heaters, to stabilize the heater circuit current against fluctuating supply voltage. In 1930s Europe it was popular to combine them in the same glass envelope with an [[negative temperature coefficient|NTC]]-type [[thermistor]] made of [[Uranium dioxide|UO<sub>2</sub>]] until 1936, known as ''Urdox resistor'' and acting as an [[inrush current limiter]] for the series heater strings of domestic [[AC/DC receiver design#Series tube heaters|ac/dc]] tube radios.
==See also== {{Portal|Electronics}} * [[Hot wire barretter]] * [[Constant-current diode]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=fB6X20Xb16cC&pg=PP1&dq=Praktikum+der+Physik+von+Wilhelm+Walcher&sig=MaaFmnK7TeK_SnCdxxUsmdRy9k0#PPP1,M1 Praktikum der Physik von Wilhelm Walcher] Page 241 *[http://museumvictoria.com.au/collections/items/412007/electronic-valve-amperite-regulator-type-4a1-1930-1949 Regulator, Type 4A1, Museum of Victoria exhibit No: ST 029230 ] *Paleoelectronics RDH4 [http://paleoelectronics.com/RDH4/CHAPTR33.PDF Ch 33], [http://paleoelectronics.com/RDH4/CHAPTR35.PDF Ch 35]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Iron-Hydrogen Resistor}} [[Category:Resistive components]] [[Category:Hydrogen technologies]]

page.title: L'ArrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = L'arrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat | image = Cinematograph Lumiere advertisement 1895.jpg | image_size = | caption = An early LumiÃ¨re advertisement | director = [[Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re|Auguste LumiÃ¨re
Louis LumiÃ¨re]] | producer = Auguste LumiÃ¨re
Louis LumiÃ¨re | writer = | narrator = | starring = | music = | cinematography = Louis LumiÃ¨re | editing = | distributor = SociÃ©tÃ© LumiÃ¨re | studio = SociÃ©tÃ© LumiÃ¨re | released = {{film date|1896|1|25|df=yes}} | runtime = 50 seconds | country = France | language = [[Silent film|Silent]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''L'arrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat''''' (translated from French into English as '''''The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat Station''''', '''''Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat''''' (US) and '''''The Arrival of the Mail Train''''', and in the United Kingdom the film is known as '''''Train Pulling into a Station''''') is an [[1896 in film|1896]] [[France|French]] [[Short subject|short]] [[black-and-white]] [[silent film|silent]] [[documentary film]] directed and produced by [[Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re]]. Contrary to myth, it was not shown at the LumiÃ¨res' first public film screening on 28 December 1895 in [[Paris]], [[France]]: the programme of ten films shown that day makes no mention of it. Its first public showing took place in January 1896. ==Content== [[File:L'ArrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat.jpg|left|thumb|The train moving directly towards the camera was said to have terrified spectators at the first screening, a claim that has been called an [[urban legend]].]] This 50-second silent film shows the entry of a train pulled by a [[steam locomotive]] into the [[gare de La Ciotat]], the train station of the French coastal town of [[La Ciotat]]. Like most of the early LumiÃ¨re films, ''L'arrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat'' consists of a single, unedited view illustrating an aspect of everyday life. There is no apparent intentional camera movement, and the film consists of one continuous real-time shot. ==Production== This 50-second movie was filmed in [[La Ciotat]], [[Bouches-du-RhÃ´ne]], [[France]]. It was filmed by means of the [[CinÃ©matographe]], an all-in-one camera, which also serves as a printer and film projector. As with all early LumiÃ¨re movies, this film was made in a [[35 mm film|35 mm format]] with an [[Aspect ratio (image)|aspect ratio]] of 1.33:1.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0000012/technical |title=Technical Specifications |work=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=2007-03-27 }} ==Contemporary reaction== [[File:L'Arrivee d'un train en gare de la Ciotat, 1895.ogv|thumb|''L'Arrivee d'un train en gare de la Ciotat'', 1895]] The film is associated with an [[urban legend]] well known in the world of cinema. The story goes that when the film was first shown, the audience was so overwhelmed by the moving image of a life-sized train coming directly at them that people screamed and ran to the back of the room. [[Hellmuth Karasek]] in the German magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' wrote that the film "had a particularly lasting impact; yes, it caused fear, terror, even panic.""Ein Kurzfilm wirkte besonders nachhaltig, ja er erzeugte Furcht, Schrecken, sogar Panik." http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-13687466.html However, some have doubted the veracity of this incident such as film scholar and historian {{ill|Martin Loiperdinger|de}} in his essay, "Lumiere's Arrival of the Train: Cinema's Founding Myth".''The Moving Image'': Volume 4, Number 1, Spring 2004, pp. 89-118) Others such as theorist [[Benjamin H. Bratton]] have speculated that the alleged reaction may have been caused by the projection being mistaken for a [[camera obscura]] by the audience which at the time would have been the only other technique to produce a naturalistic moving image. Whether or not it actually happened, the film undoubtedly astonished people unaccustomed to the illusion created by moving images. ==Cinematic techniques== This film is interesting because it contains the first example of several common [[cinematic techniques]]: [[camera angle]], [[long shot]], [[medium shot]], [[close-up]], and [[forced perspective]]. It is evident from their films, taken as a whole, that the LumiÃ¨re brothers knew what the effect of their choice of camera placement would be. They placed the camera on the platform to produce a dramatic increase in the size of the arriving train. The train arrives from a distant point and bears down on the viewer, finally crossing the lower edge of the screen. A significant aspect of the film is that it illustrates the use of the long shot to establish the setting of the film, followed by a medium shot, and then a close-up. As the camera is static for the entire film, the effect of these various "shots" is achieved by the movement of the subject alone. Nonetheless, it is these different types of shots are clearly illustrated here, and later film makers moved their cameras to achieve these shots. ==3D version== What most film histories leave out is that the LumiÃ¨re Brothers were trying to achieve a [[Stereoscopy|3D image]] even prior to this first-ever public exhibition of motion pictures. Louis LumiÃ¨re eventually re-shot ''L'ArrivÃ©e dâun Train'' with a stereoscopic film camera and exhibited it (along with a series of other 3D shorts) at a 1935 meeting of the French Academy of Science. Given the contradictory accounts that plague early cinema and pre-cinema accounts, it's plausible that early cinema historians conflated the audience reactions at these separate screenings of ''L'ArrivÃ©e dâun Train''. The intense audience reaction fits better with the latter exhibition, when the train apparently ''was'' actually coming out of the screen at the audience. But due to the fact that the [[3D film]] never took off commercially as the conventional 2D version did, including such details would not make for a compelling myth.{{cite web |url=http://www.editorsguild.com/v2/magazine/archives/0508/columns_cutprint2.htm |title=Editors Guild Magazine - Cut/Print |publisher=Editorsguild.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021155402/http://www.editorsguild.com/v2/magazine/archives/0508/columns_cutprint2.htm |archivedate=2012-10-21 |df= }} ==Current status== [[File:Les frÃ¨res LumiÃ©res quai de la gare de la Ciotat france.jpg|thumb|The [[Gare de La Ciotat|La Ciotat train station]] (shown here in 2010) commemorates the film.]] The short has been featured in a number of film collections including ''Landmarks of Early Film volume 1''.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0000012/dvd |title=DVD |work=Internet Movie Database |accessdate=2007-03-27 }} A screening of the film was depicted in the 2011 film ''[[Hugo (film)|Hugo]]''. The scene of the train pulling in was placed at #100 on [[Channel 4|Channel 4's]] two-part documentary ''[[The 100 Greatest Scary Moments]]''. In March 2017, the film was encoded into DNA by [[Yaniv Erlich]] and Dina Zielinski.{{cite journal|last1=Erlich|first1=Yaniv|last2=Zielinski|first2=Dina|title=DNA Fountain enables a robust and efficient storage architecture|journal=Science|date=2 March 2017|volume=355|issue=6328|pages=950â954|doi=10.1126/science.aaj2038|url=http://www.biorxiv.org/content/biorxiv/early/2016/12/04/074237.full.pdf}}{{cite web|last1=Yong|first1=Ed|title=This Speck of DNA Contains a Movie, a Computer Virus, and an Amazon Gift Card|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2017/03/this-speck-of-dna-contains-a-movie-a-computer-virus-and-an-amazon-gift-card/518373/|website=The Atlantic|accessdate=18 March 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0000012|title=L'ArrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat}} * {{Internet Archive film|id=youtube--e1u7Fgoocc}} *[http://www.institut-lumiere.org/ The Lumiere Institute, Lyon, France] * [http://cinemaven.org/larrivee-dun-train-en-gare-de-la-ciotat/ ''L'ArrivÃ©e d'un train en gare de La Ciotat'': an interpretation] at the [http://cinemaven.org/ Cinemaven blog]. {{Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arrivee d'un train en gare de La Ciotat, L'}} [[Category:1895 films]] [[Category:French black-and-white films]] [[Category:French documentary films]] [[Category:History of film]] [[Category:French silent short films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Documentary films about rail transport]] [[Category:History of rail transport in France]] [[Category:Rail transport films]] [[Category:Films directed by Auguste and Louis LumiÃ¨re]] [[Category:French 3D films]] [[Category:1890s documentary films]] [[Category:Black-and-white documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about France]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:3D short films]]

page.title: Limitations on exclusive rights: Computer programs

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP;add/change/refine category; MOS fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Limitations on exclusive rights: Computer programs''' is the title of the current form of section 117 of the U.S. Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. Â§ 117). In [[United States copyright law]], it provides users with certain adaptation rights for computer software that they own. ==Background== The current form of section 117 is the result of a recommendation by [[CONTU]], the National Commission on New Technological Uses of Copyrighted Works. The U.S. Congress established CONTU to study and make recommendations on modifying the 1976 Copyright Act to deal with new technologies, particularly computer software, that Congress had not addressed when it passed the 1976 Act. CONTU operated from 1975 to 1978, and its principal recommendation to Congress was to revise the wording of section 117. Its report stated:
Because the placement of a work into a computer is the preparation of a copy, the law should provide that persons in rightful possession of copies of programs be able to use them freely without fear of exposure to copyright liability. Obviously, creators, lessors, licensors, and vendors of copies of programs intend that they be used by their customers, so that rightful users would but rarely need a legal shield against potential copyright problems. It is easy to imagine, however, a situation in which the copyright owner might desire, for good reason or none at all, to force a lawful owner or possessor of a copy to stop using a particular program. One who rightfully possesses a copy of a program, therefore, should be provided with a legal right to copy it to that extent which will permit its use by that possessor. This would include the right to load it into a computer and to prepare archival copies of it to guard against destruction or damage by mechanical or electrical failure. But this permission would not extend to other copies of the program. Thus, one could not, for example, make archival copies of a program and later sell some while retaining some for use. The sale of a copy of a program by a rightful possessor to another must be of all rights in the program, thus creating a new rightful possessor and destroying that status as regards the seller.
The revisions recommended by CONTU were approved with one important change. Instead of "rightful possessor" of a computer program Congress used the word "owner" of a computer program. It is not clear why this change was made.According to Professor Holaar, [http://digital-law-online.info/lpdi1.0/treatise17.html Digital Law Online: History].Â§ I.E.1: "There is nothing in the legislative history of the bill that indicates why this change was made. Perhaps the best explanation is that Congress was concerned that people would make copies of software they had rented or borrowed from a public library, where they were rightful possessors during the time they had the software, and then not delete the copies when they return the software to the rental place or library." This one change resulted in a state of affairs in which software vendors began to take the position that customers do not own their software but rather only "license" it. The courts have split on whether the assertion in software agreements that the customer does not own the software, and has only a right to use it in accordance with the license agreement, is legally enforceable.For example, in ''Krause v. Titleserv, Inc.'', 402 F.3d 119 (2d Cir. 2005), the Second Circuit held that "Congress's decision to reject 'rightful possessor' in favor of 'owner' [did] not indicate an intention to limit the protection of the statute to those possessing formal title." ''Id''. at 123. Rather, "formal title in a program copy is not an absolute prerequisite to qualifying for [shelter under Â§ 117]. Instead, courts should inquire into whether the party exercises sufficient incidents of ownership over a copy of the program to be sensibly considered the owner of the copy for purposes of Â§ 117(a)." ''Id.'' at 124. On the other hand, in ''MAI Systems Corp. v. Peak Computer, Inc.'', the Ninth Circuit held Â§ 117 inapplicable to a customer because "MAI software licenses [did] not allow for the use or copying of MAI software by third parties such as [repair and maintenance persons]." The court also said: "Since MAI licensed its software, the [] customers [were licensees of MAI and] do not qualify as 'owners' of the software and are not eligible for protection under Â§ 117." ''Id''. at 518 n.5. ==Users' rights under Â§ 117== Section 117 is a limitation on the rights granted to holders of copyright on [[computer program]]s. The limitation allows the owner of a particular copy of a copyrighted computer program to make copies or adaptations of the program for any of several reasons: # Utilization of the program. The user is allowed to install the software to his [[hard disk]] and run the software in random-access memory. # Making [[backup]] and [[archive|archival]] copies. The user is allowed to make copies of the software to protect himself from loss in the event of the original distribution media being damaged. # Making copies of software in order to repair or maintain machines, provided that the copies used in repairing the machine is destroyed after the repair or maintenance is complete. The law allows any copies that are created for the above purposes to be transferred when the software is sold, only along with the copy made to prepare them. Adaptations made can not be transferred without permission from the copyright holder. == Reverse engineering == While it is not part of section 117, it is also lawful to [[reverse engineering|reverse engineer]] software for compatibility purposes. Sec. 103(f) of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act|DMCA]] ([https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/1201- 17 U.S.C. Â§ 1201 (f)]) says that a person who is in legal possession of a program, is permitted to reverse-engineer and circumvent its protection against copying if this is necessary in order to achieve "interoperability" - a term broadly covering other devices and programs being able to interact with it, make use of it, and to use and transfer data to and from it, in useful ways. A limited exemption exists that allows the knowledge thus gained to be shared and used for interoperability purposes. More generally, it has been held that reverse engineering is a fair use.The Federal Circuit so held in ''[[Atari Games Corp. v. Nintendo of America Inc.]]'' (interoperability case). In ''[[Sega v. Accolade]]'', the Ninth Circuit held that making copies in the course of [[reverse engineering]] is a fair use, when it is the only way to get access to the "ideas and functional elements" in the copyrighted code, and when "there is a legitimate reason for seeking such access."See also ''[[Sony Computer Entertainment, Inc. v. Connectix Corp.]]'' (reverse engineering to make emulator). == See also == * [[Software patents under United States patent law]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap1.html#117 Text of section 117] * [http://digital-law-online.info/CONTU/contu1.html CONTU Final Draft] [[Category:Computer law]] [[Category:United States copyright law]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/Anujkuu|Anujkuu]] ([[User talk:Anujkuu|talk]]) to last version by Mauls
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=August 2017}}
{{Infobox building | name = Link Electronics Ltd. | owner = Link Electronics Ltd | address = | location_town = [[Andover, Hampshire]] | location_country = [[England]] }}
'''Link Electronics Ltd'''. was a major UK industrial and [[Terrestrial television|broadcast television]] equipment manufacturer and systems integrator in the 1970s and 1980s. The company was founded by John Tanner and David Mann, who began manufacturing television cameras in 1966.<ref name=âInvestorsChronicleâ>{{cite book|title=Investors Chronicle & Financial World|page=575|year=1981|publisher=Throgmorton Publications}}</ref> Link was mainly known for its range of broadcast television cameras, but was also a manufacturer of outside broadcast (OB) vehicles, including the famous [[BBC]] "Type 5". Link also produced a wide range of ancillary studio equipment, such as [[distribution amplifiers]], measuring sets and test signal generators.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.amcro.co.uk/link/ |title=LINK Electronics |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=amcro |publisher= |access-date=August 4, 2017}}</ref>
==Cameras==
Link started as an industrial camera manufacturer but soon moved into broadcast equipment when the BBC approached it to develop a successor to the commercially successful [[EMI 2001]], when EMI's own design for the 2001's successor, the 2005, failed to meet expected standards when launched around 1975. The poor performance of this camera considering its development cost led to EMI exiting the broadcast camera industry. A similar fate befell Link around 10â15 years later upon the release of the Link 130 (further down this page).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.golden-agetv.co.uk/equipment.php?ProducerID=25 |vauthors = Howett D, Marshall P|title=Equipment produced by LINK|date= |website=Golden Age Television Recreations |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>
=== Type 109 ===
The Type 109 was a broadcast quality black and white camera mainly used as a caption scanner or simple tele-cine.<ref name="Museum">{{cite web |url=http://www.tvcameramuseum.org/link/link_thumbnails.html |title=Link Electronics Camera Thumbnails |last=Summers |first=Brian |date= |website= |publisher=Museum of Broadcast television Camera |access-date=August 4, 2017 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
=== Type 100 === The Link-NEC 100 was the companion camera to the Type 130 and designed in conjunction with NEC. It had a triax interface unit and could be used stand alone, via a radio link or with a CCU via triax cable. it shared a common architecture with the 130 by using the same 18mm tubes and both where fully automatic for set-up and used the same CCU (Camera Control Unit), OCP (operational Control Unit) and MSU (Master Setup Unit) <ref name="Museum"/>
=== Type 110/111 === The 110 was Link's first attempt at a colour broadcast camera and around 200 cameras were manufactured. Styling was based on the famous [[EMI 2001]] colour camera but at an economical price, including what some claim to be a very flimsy casing that was not of rugged design. The camera consisted of a closed body and an internal lens from a range of manufacturers, like the [[EMI 2001]], leading to similar claims that the design was "boxy". The camera was capable of both studio and outside broadcast use and at the BBC found its way into TC6, TC8 and several presentation studios at [[BBC Television Centre|Television Centre]], BBC Lime Grove, BBC Bristol, the [[Open University]] studio in Milton Keynes, BBC Wood Norton Training Centre and onto several BBC outside broadcast vehicles. ITV company [[Thames Television]] also used them at their Euston road studios from around 1979, replacing their Marconi MkVIIs (with RCA TK-47s at Teddington a few years later replacing the EMI 2001s there). The 110 was seen as a good, cheap, modern option which was lightweight and easier to carry compared to the much older and heavier [[EMI 2001]] camera.<ref name="Museum"/>
=== Type 120 === The Link 120 was a portable camera system that consisted of the camera head and a portable electronics box that then connected to the CCU via standard TV36 multicore cable. The Type 120 was intended to be able to 'clip' into a studio frame to allow easy conversion from either a handheld camera on location or to a large lens camera at sports events in studio. An advert in the Guild of Television Cameramen magazine ZERB notes that there are three options. the Type 121 shoulder mount (with long 3 inch viewfinder) Type 122 with 3 inch viewfinder, Type 123 in sports camera body and 5 inch viewfinder and the Type 124 with full studio lens and 7 inch viewfinder. The Link 125 camera was the next step to purpose designed studio camera.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gtc.org.uk/publications/zerb.aspx |title=Zerb |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=The Guild of Television Camera Professionals |publisher=GTC |access-date=|subscription=y}}</ref>
===Type 125=== The Link 125 camera was purchased in quantity by the BBC and deployed to most of the studios at Television Centre, Pebble Mill in Birmingham and Belfast as well as several other BBC studios. It was also the camera of choice at Limehouse Television. In addition, [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] company [[Television South]] (TVS) used the model in its [[Maidstone]] studios, which were still in use by those studios when they were sold off as an independent studio facility following the loss of TVS's franchise at the end of 1992. The 125 was a well thought out and well-built studio and OB camera developed from the Link 120 portable camera system. It also contained a comprehensive communications system and used a camera control unit (CCU) based around the 110's but updated with auto black, white, iris and centering functions. The BBC preferred to use a mid range Schneider-Kreuznach lens as it gave good zoom angles. Some believed it produced one of the best images for a pickup tube camera, others believed it could never match the quality of the [[EMI 2001]]. Many BBC users felt that the image was soft and not easy to focus, it also produced an unusual image effect that formed the shape of a 'teardrop'<ref name="Museum"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pebblemill.org/blog/link-125-cameras/ |title=Link 125 cameras |author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website=Pebble Mill studios |publisher=Birmingham City University |access-date=August 4, 2017}} </ref> The Link 125 was the most successful of all of Links cameras and the last studio to use them was BBC Pebble Mill which decommissioned the last four in 1994 from the news studio having upgraded to Sony BVP-375's and Ikegami HL-55's a few years before. These cameras have become collectable vintage items. <ref name=âOnTheAirâ>{{cite web |url=http://www.vintageradio.co.uk/htm/TVcollection.htm |title=Cameras |last=Harris |first=Steve |date= |website=On The Air |publisher= |access-date= August 10, 2017}}</ref>
===Type 130=== The 130 was designed in the mid 1980s as a high tech modern camera with aspirations of quality and high tech design through the use of microprocessors for full auto setup. Unfortunately it soon became apparent that there were several hardware and/or software errors made during the design and manufacture of this model, which seriously affected the manufacturer's reputation with its broadcast customer base, much in the same way the 2005 had done for EMI around 15 years before. This was compounded by competition from high quality camera systems from Japanese manufacturers including Sony, Ikegami and Hitachi and by the Dutch manufacturer [[Philips]]. Also at this time [[RCA]] had started to use [[Charge-coupled device|CCDs]] in its cameras which produced what was considered a superior picture to the then prevailing technology of camera pickup tubes, which necessitated not so many regular adjustments in their setup procedures.
In the mid-1980s the BBC was designing the Type 6 Scanner and had chosen the Link 100 and 130 and had several camera channels for testing. Prototypes had been sent to Israel, Sweden and Australia. The BBC Link 130 cameras were initially installed in Elstree Studio A along with some NEC MNC-100 lightweight cameras. Sadly, they proved to be very unreliable. They had been around for a few years in development and the idea was to use studio A and BBC Glasgow as test beds to try to make them work. (John Wardle (Head of BBC Engineering) stated that 42 130s were ordered but only 11 delivered - BBC Glasgow was the studio to receive the first batch, much to the frustration of those who used them.)
Unfortunately as the camera suffered from poor design and many software bugs (that would leave the camera's automatic lineup software switched on and the cue light happening to cause picture interference), the BBC engineering department felt that these faults wouldn't be fixed quickly and opted for [[Thomson Broadcast|Thomson]] Cameras. As a result, this act allegedly caused the final collapse of Link, which was declared bankrupt. UEI Group then briefly purchased the Company, after investing many hundreds of thousands of pounds in the development of the camera only for the poor design not being rectified in the design or prototype stages giving Link a poor reputation after several technically and commercially successful models. The company then transferred to the ownership of Quantel.
There are several units in private collections and until the early 2000s several casings were to be seen at the [[National Science and Media Museum]] in Bradford as part of a public display.<ref name="Museum"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/23471228/bbc-cameras-be-supplied-by-link-electronics |title=BBC Cameras to be supplied by Link Electronics |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=June 1985 |website=Ebsco Host |publisher= |access-date=August 4, 2017 |subscription=y}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbceng.info/Eng_Inf/EngInf_25.pdf |title=enginef The Quarterly for BBC Engineering Staff |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=Summer 1986 |website= |publisher=BBC Engineering |access-date=August 4, 2016}}</ref>
==Studio Equipment== Link produced a full range of sync pulse generators, [[Video-signal generator|colour bar generators]], video distribution amps and various other pieces of industrial and broadcast television equipment.
Including -
===107 Camera Tube Test Channel=== A Plumbicon tube condition tester
===251 Colour Syncrohnising Pulse Generator=== A Colour Syncrohnising Pulse Generator including mixed sysnc and blanking, line and field, PAL Subcarrier and PAL ident
===255 Series PAL Encoder=== A PAL Ecncoder with picture input and three composite outputs. Optional modules could produce Black and Burst signal and Colour Bars.
===260 Series PSU===
===286 Rack Frame=== 8 Module rack from and space for a 260 Series PSU.
===260 Series Generators=== Worked with the 251 Sync Generator.
260 Ramp Generator 261 RGB Colour Bar Generator 262 PAL Black and Burst Generator 263 Grille and Dot Generator 264 Step Staircase Generator 265 PLUGE Generator 268 Phase Locked Sweep Generator 271 6In to 1Out Selector panel 272 PAL burst Adder
===Type 280 Video Distribution Amplifier=== A universally mains powered video/sync distribution amp with six individual isolated outputs. A rack frame was available to contain up to 8 modules
===290 Video Delay=== 290 Single Channel Delay and 291 Triple channel Delay that where housed in the 280 type chassis.
===329 Waveform generator=== Generates a 5 step Staircase pattern, Peak White and Black signals and PAL sub-carriers.
===360 Video Noise Meter=== A devise for checking the signal quality of a video signal
===375 Insertion Test Generator===
===700 Series Talkback/Intercomm=== Link 700 series intercomm where custom built systems using computerized FET cross-point switching with selector panels and feeds to and from VT's and cameras.
===710 Directors Talkback=== Specially designed for EFP (Electronic Field Production) applications. It consisted of three control panel's (Director, Vision Engineer and Sound Engineer) which had access to each other as well as a maximum of four cameras and an auxiliary feed (production sound).
===760 Series Audio Distribution=== 760 1In - 8Out Audio Distribution amplifier 762 Rear Connector Assembly
===787 Telephone Exchange=== A telephone exchange system capable of working with up to 10n external lines and up to five operating positions, each position having a keypad with an illuminated push button for each line and a buzzer that sounded for 2 seconds when an incoming call was received.
==Outside Broadcast Vehicles== PYE TVT had supplied the BBC with its television OB vehicles from the mid 1960s until the early 1980s. When the Type 5 was being designed Link offered a design that provided a full facility unit with up to eight cameras (although BBC OBs chose the Philips LDK-5, not a Link camera) at least 20 were supplied to the BBC and five to ITV and foreign customers. One Type 5 (London 6) was donated to the Science Museum.<ref name="Museum"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvobhistory.co.uk/bbc-cmcrs---colour.html |title=TV Outside Broadcast History|author=<!--Not stated--> |date= |website= |publisher=TV Outside Broadcast History |access-date=August 4, 2017}}</ref>
==Quantel-Link== Following its bankruptcy, UK digital broadcast equipment manufacture [[Quantel]], famous for the Paintbox graphics system, acquired the company and used it to develop a facilities integration and design company known as Quantel-Link. This company continued to design and manufacture outside broadcast vehicles to many national broadcasters including YTE in Finland as well as companies in France, Germany and other European broadcasters.
== External links == * [http://www.tech-ops.co.uk/ BBC Tech Ops History Site] * [http://www.tvcameramuseum.org/emi/emi_thumbnails.htm Museum of the Broadcast Television Camera] * [http://www.tvstudiohistory.co.uk/ The website of Martin Kempton] on London television studios contains much on the industries use of various cameras over the decades, including the Link 110 and 125.
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:TTO Nanochannel Glass Materials.jpg|thumb|300px|Nanochannel glass materials are complex glass structures containing large numbers of parallel hollow channels. Source: [[Naval Research Laboratory]] - Technology Transfer Office.]]
'''Nanochannel glass materials''' are an experimental [[photomask|mask]] technology that is an alternate method for fabricating [[nanostructures]], although [[optical lithography]] is the predominant patterning technique.<ref name=gmz> {{Cite book |editor-last=Gimzewski |editor-first=James K |editor2=Welland, M.E | title =Ultimate limits of fabrication and measurement | publisher =Springer | date =May 1995 | pages =13, 14, 15 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=5p3Z1fEI0xwC&pg=PA14&dq=Nanochannel+Glass+Materials&cd=2#v=onepage&q&f=false | isbn =978-0-7923-3504-7}} * Proceedings of the NATO Advanced Research Workshop, Cambridge, U.K., April 1--3, 1994 Series: NATO Science Series E: (closed), Vol. 292</ref>
Nanochannel glass materials are [[complex glass]] structures containing large numbers of parallel hollow channels. In its simplest form, the hollow channels are arranged in geometric arrays with packing densities as great as 10<sup>11</sup> channels/cm<sup>2</sup>. Channel dimensions are controllable from micrometers to tens of nanometers, while retaining excellent channel uniformity. Exact replicas of the channel glass can be made from a variety of materials. This is a low cost method for creating identical structures with nanoscale features in large numbers.<ref name=nrl-ncm/><ref name=Tonuccia/>
==Characteristics== These materials have high density of uniform channels with diameters from 15 micrometres to 15 nanometers. These are rigid structures with serviceable temperatures to at least 300 Â°C, with potential up to 1000 Â°C. Furthermore, these are optically transparent photonic structures with high degree of reproducibility.
==Applications== These can be used as a material for [[chromatography|chromatographic columns]], unidirectional [[Electrical conductor|conductor]]s, [[Microchannel plate detector|Microchannel plate]] and [[nonlinear optical devices]]. Other uses are as masks for [[semiconductor]] development, including ion implantation, optical lithography, and [[reactive ion etching]].<ref name=nrl-ncm> {{Cite web | title =Nanochannel Glass Materials | publisher =Naval Research Laboratory. Technology Transfer Office, Code 1004 | url =http://www.nrl.navy.mil/techtransfer/fs.php?fs_id=MAT13 | accessdate =2011-07-04}} *{{USGovernment-Navy}} </ref><ref name=Tonuccia> {{cite conference |doi=10.1063/1.2821605 |title=Materials Characterization and Nanofabrication MethodsâNanochannel Glass Materials |book-title=AIP Conference Proceedings |year=2007 |last1=Tonucci|first1=Ronald J.|last2=Hubler|first2=Graham K. |editor-last=Sibilia |editor-first=Concita |editor-last2=Wiersma |editor-first2=Diederik S. |volume=959 |pages=59â71 |isbn=978-0-7354-0473-1}}</ref><ref name=Pearson>{{cite journal|doi=10.1126/science.270.5233.68|title=Nanochannel Glass Replica Membranes|year=1995|last1=Pearson|first1=D. H.|last2=Tonucci|first2=R. J.|journal=Science|volume=270|issue=5233|pages=68â70|bibcode = 1995Sci...270...68P }}</ref>
==See also== *[[E-beam lithography]] *[[Ion beam lithography]] *[[Maskless lithography]] *[[Nanolithography]] *[[Photolithography]] *[[Porous glass]] *[[Vycor|Vycor glass]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite conference |doi = 10.1117/12.351044 |url = http://lib.semi.ac.cn:8080/tsh/dzzy/wsqk/SPIE/vol3609/3609-67.pdf |title = Near-field scanning optical microscopy imaging: theory, simulation, and experiment |book-title = Proceedings of SPIE |year = 1999 |last1 = Bryant |first1 = Garnett W. |volume = 3609 |pages = 67â75 |series = Optical Pulse and Beam Propagation |editor1-last = Band |editor1-first = Yehuda B |last2 = Liu |first2 = Ansheng |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120317142550/http://lib.semi.ac.cn:8080/tsh/dzzy/wsqk/SPIE/vol3609/3609-67.pdf |archivedate = 2012-03-17 |df = }} *{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.270.5233.68 |url= |title=Nanochannel Glass Replica Membranes |year=1995 |last1=Pearson |first1=D. H. |last2=Tonucci |first2=R. J. |journal=Science |volume=270 |issue=5233 |pages=68|bibcode = 1995Sci...270...68P }} * {{US patent|5,976,444}} "''Nanochannel glass replica membranes''"
[[Category:Materials science]] [[Category:Glass]] [[Category:Glass engineering and science]] [[Category:Glass applications]]

The research project '''OSAMI-E''' is the [[Spain| Spanish]] subproject of the European [http://www.itea2.org/ ITEA ''2''] project [http://www.osami-commons.org OSAMI] ('''O'''pen '''S'''ource '''AM'''bient '''I'''ntelligence).
The aim of the international project [http://www.osami-commons.org OSAMI] is the design of a basic, widely applicable [[Service-oriented architecture|SOA]]-oriented component platform, its development, test and its provision as [[Open Source|open source]] software. The project consists of a number of national sub-projects, each focussing on a certain field of application.
[[OSGi]] and [[Web Services]] forms the technical basis of the OSAMI platform in order to implement distributed, dynamically configurable, vendor-neutral and device-independent solutions.
The Spanish sub-project OSAMI-E, funded by the [https://web.archive.org/web/20091207090817/http://www7.mityc.es/ Spanish Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Commerce], contributes to different transversal areas such as engineering, architecture, tools and security and with demonstrators in the fields of education, geographic information systems, sensor networks, digital home and mobile services.
;Project data :Supporting organisations: [http://www.itea2.org/ ITEA2],[https://web.archive.org/web/20091207090817/http://www7.mityc.es/ Spanish Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Commerce] :Duration: 01.04.2008 - 30.03.2011
==General information== The main objective of [http://www.osami-commons.org OSAMI] is to connect technologically vertical markets on the basis of an open platform and, hence, to facilitate the market entry for [[Small and medium enterprises|small and medium-sized enterprises (SME)]].
===Technical and Scientific Objectives of OSAMI-E=== # Establishment of common engineering principles # Establishment of common architecture for interoperability # Linking vertical domains through the common platform # Demonstrate the platform # Elaborate policy and acquisition recommendations
===Participants=== *[http://www.aicia.es Aicia] *[http://www.uc3m.es Universidad Carlos III de Madrid] *[http://www.cenatic.es Cenatic] *[http://www.cit.gva.es Conselleria de Infraestructures y Transporte] *[http://www.esi.es European Software Institute] *[http://www.fidetia.es Fidetia] *[http://www.upm.es Universidad PolitÃ©cnica de Madrid (UPM)] *[http://www.upv.es Universidad PolitÃ©cnica de Valencia (UPV)] *[http://www.prodevelop.es Prodevelop] *[http://www.rediris.es RedIRIS ] *[http://www.telefonica.com TelefÃ³nica] *[http://www.telvent.com Telvent] *[http://www.uma.es University of MÃ¡laga] *[http://www.uvigo.es University of Vigo] *[http://www.vodafone.com Vodafone]
===Work Packages and Tasks=== *WP 1: Coordination and Dissemination *WP 2: Business, Trust and Processes *WP 3: Organisation, Tools and Training *WP 4: Vertical Domains *WP 5: OSAMI Interface & Architecture *WP 6: Security, Assets and User interface issues *WP 7: Demonstrators
==External links== *[http://www.osami-commons.org OSAMI] *[http://www.itea2.org/ ITEA ''2''] *[http://www.eureka.org/ Eureka] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091207090817/http://www7.mityc.es/ Spanish Ministry of Industry, Tourism and Commerce]
[[Category:Eureka (organisation)]] [[Category:Information technology organizations]]

[[File:OU Campus logo.png|235px|right]] '''OU Campus''' is a web [[content management system]] (CMS) for colleges, universities, and other [[higher education]] institutions.<ref>{{cite web|last=Fienen|first=Michael|title=Results: Higher Ed CMA Usage Survey, 2011|url=http://doteduguru.com/id7800-results-higher-ed-cms-usage-survey-2011.html|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref>
OU Campus was launched in 1999 using the [[cloud computing]], [[software as a service]] (SaaS) product delivery model.<ref>{{cite news|last=Merker|first=Lance|title=Considering Enterprise Software as a Service?|url=http://www.universitybusiness.com/article/considering-enterprise-software-service|accessdate=7 November 2012|newspaper=University Business|date=November 2009}}</ref> It was developed by OmniUpdate, a privately owned company headquartered in [[Camarillo]], CA. OmniUpdate was started by software developers Tom Nalevanko, Lance Merker, and Yves Lempereur (developer of [[BinHex]] 4.0).
==Technology== The product uses a [[push technology]]. OU Campus can be accessed via the cloud - also known as software as a service (SaaS). The underlying platform of OU Campus is developed in [[Java (programming language)|Java]], and uses [[XSLT]] 3.0 for template transformation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Merker|first=Lance|title=OmniUpdate Releases Version 9 | url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/OmniUpdate-Releases-Version-9-iw-225235719.html}}</ref> OU Campus uses open standards, including XML, HTML, and CSS and is extensible through APIs. As a decoupled system, OU Campus works with any server-side technology (e.g., [[PHP]], [[Active Server Pages|ASP]], [[.NET Framework|.NET]], [[ColdFusion]]) and for templates uses [[XHTML]]/[[HTML5]] and [[CSS]], as well as [[XML]]/[[XSL]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Merker|first=Lance|title=Learning to Leverage XML for Higher Ed Web CMS | url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/web-cms/learning-to-leverage-xml-for-higher-ed-web-cms-001438.php}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Schaffhauser|first=Dian|title=9 Best Practices for Implementing a CMS | url=http://campustechnology.com/Articles/2007/09/9-Best-Practices-for-Implementing-a-CMS.aspx?Page=2 }}</ref> The templates are customizable so that developers can create sites using popular web development techniques including [[Responsive web design]] to adapt to all screen sizes and devices. OU Campus does not store page content in a [[database]]; rather, each page is stored as an XML file on the CMS server. It is compatible with [[Internet Explorer]], [[Firefox]], [[Google Chrome]], and [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]]. OU Campus' push technology architecture requires a separate database for some applications that use interactive content such as forms and surveys. These applications can be handled through the Live Delivery Platform (LDP), which provides a server-side module for plug-in application architecture. LDP is accessed and managed through OU Campus.<ref>{{cite web|last=Spick|first=Geoff|title=Digital Asset Management Takes Front Seat for Higher Education Web CMS|url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/web-cms/digital-asset-management-takes-front-seat-for-higher-education-web-cms-009046.php|publisher=CMS Wire|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref>
==Features== * Custom [[WYSIWYG]] toolbars * Source code editing * Instant publishing (no queues) * Multi-channel output (e.g., HTML, XML, PDF, text, mobile) * Content repurposing<ref>{{cite web|last=Berthiaume|first=Dan|title=OmniUpdate Enhances Content Reuse in OUCampus Update|url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/customer-experience/omniupdate-enhances-content-reuse-in-oucampus-update-015608.php }}</ref> -- OU Campus allows users to repurpose content through Assets. Changes made to an asset are automatically changed on every page where that asset resides. * Accessibility check * Analytics * Multi-browser preview * [[Asset management]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Spick|first=Geoff|title=Digital Asset Management Takes Front Seat for Higher Education Web CMS|url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/web-cms/digital-asset-management-takes-front-seat-for-higher-education-web-cms-009046.php }}</ref> * [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]] integration<ref>{{cite web|last=Guseva|first=Irina|title=OmniUpdate Adds Social Features to Web CMS|url=http://www.cmswire.com/cms/web-cms/omniupdate-adds-social-features-to-web-cms-008345.php }}</ref> * Global find and replace * Updates made to web pages can be simultaneously made to mobile pages * OU Campus separates content from design, so users can style their content without breaking the page layout and design
==Known customers== {{refimprove section|date=May 2013}} * [[Eastern Michigan University]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.emich.edu/communications/web/training/login.php|title = Eastern Michigan University: Division of Communications|website = www.emich.edu|access-date = 2016-07-11}}</ref> * [[Kansas State University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Content Management System|url=http://www.k-state.edu/webservices/cms/}}</ref> * [[University of Denver]]<ref>{{cite web|title=University Technology Services|url=http://www.du.edu/uts/webwork/training.html}}</ref> * [[Pepperdine University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Submit an Announcement|url=http://community.pepperdine.edu/today/submission/announcements/}}</ref> * [[Michigan State University]] (Human Resources) * [[California State University, Channel Islands]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Mosinskis|first=Peter|title=Web Accessibility for Your Entire Organization with California State University Channel Islands|url=https://omniupdate.webex.com/ec0606l/eventcenter/recording/recordAction.do?theAction=poprecord&AT=pb&isurlact=true&renewticket=0&recordID=78679617&apiname=lsr.php&rKey=c60357414bd64a3d&needFilter=false&format=short&&SP=EC&rID=78679617&siteurl=omniupdate&actappname=ec0606l&actname=%2Feventcenter%2Fframe%2Fg.do&rnd=1034604754&entactname=%2FnbrRecordingURL.do&entappname=url0108l|work=OmniUpdate|publisher=WebEx|accessdate=17 October 2013|author2=Daniel Martinez}}</ref> * [[Western Kentucky University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Western Kentucky University using OU Campus|url=https://www.wku.edu/oucampus/|accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref> * [[McKendree University]]<ref>{{cite web|title=XSLT Platform Change|url=https://news.yahoo.com/xslt-platform-change-feature-enhancements-customer-drive-accomplishment-20110111-090027-784.html}}</ref> * [[Oklahoma City Community College]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Can a CMS make your job easier?|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zHDlpFH5q6U&feature=share&list=UUT1qgoZhkA3RWHHYJFSg1LQ}}</ref> * [[Elizabethtown College]] (Pennsylvania)<ref>{{cite web|title=CMS Training|url=http://www.etown.edu/offices/marketing-and-communications/guides/cms-training.aspx}}</ref> * [[Utah Valley University]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gerber|first=Nathan|title=Working In The Clouds|url=http://www.universitybusiness.com/article/working-clouds|publisher=CMS Wire}}</ref> * [[Victor Valley College]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Gatewood|first=Justin|title=How Victor Valley College is Using OmniUpdate's OU Campus|url=http://doteduguru.com/id5110-how-victor-valley-college-is-using-omniupdates-ou-campus.html|publisher=.eduGuru}}</ref> * [[Ferris State University]] * [[Stony Brook University]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Palmeri|first=Josh|title=Welcome to OU Campus|url=http://www.stonybrook.edu/ousupport}}</ref> * [[Texas Tech University]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.depts.ttu.edu/itts/web/ou/index.php|title = OmniUpdate: OU Campus|website = www.depts.ttu.edu|access-date = 2018-02-05}}</ref>
==References== <references />
== External links == * {{official website|http://omniupdate.com/|OmniUpdate Inc. official website}}

revision.comment: removed "as of January 2015" language from content license because licensing remains the same
revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = OpenStax CNX
(Connexions 1999-April 2014){{cite web|last1=Woodward|first1=Ed|title=New Name and New Editor Demo|url=http://devblog.cnx.org/2014/04/new-name-and-new-editor-demo.html|website=OpenStax CNX Developer Blog|accessdate=13 October 2015|date=April 3, 2014}} | logo = [[File:OpenStax_CNX_logo_2018.png|250 px|caption=OpenStax CNX logo]] | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = OpenStax CNX homepage in January 2015 | url = [http://cnx.org/ cnx.org] | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 40,896 ({{as of|2018|9|20|alt=September 2018}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/cnx.org |title= cnx.org Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }} | commercial = no | type = [[Open educational resources|Open Educational Resources]] | registration = free | language count = 34 | owner = [[Rice University]] | content_license = [[Creative Commons Attribution 4.0]] | launch date = {{Start date|1999}} | current status = Active | revenue = Foundation-funded non-profit | slogan = }} '''OpenStax CNX''', formerly called '''Connexions''', is a global repository of educational content provided by volunteers. The open source platform is provided and maintained by [[OpenStax College|OpenStax]], which is based at [[Rice University]]. The collection is available free of charge, can be remixed and edited, and is available for download in various digital formats.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/01/22/EDRTUJ346.DTL |title=Bringing open resources to textbooks and teaching |date= 22 January 2008 |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |first1=Jimmy |last1=Wales |first2=Rich |last2=Baraniuk}} Founded as Connexions in 1999 by [[Richard Baraniuk]], OpenStax CNX is based on the philosophy that scholarly and educational content can and should be shared, re-used and recombined, interconnected and continually enriched. As such, it was one of the first [[Open educational resources|Open Educational Resources]] (OER) initiatives along with projects such as [[MIT OpenCourseWare]] and the [[Public Library of Science]]. The materials in Connexions are available under a [[CC-BY|CC BY]] [[Creative Commons]] license, which means that content can be used, adapted, and remixed, as long as attribution is provided.Kelty, C. M. (2008). Two bits. Duke University Press. ==Subject matter== OpenStax CNX contains educational materials at all levelsâfrom children to college students to professionalsâorganized in small modules (pages) that can be connected into larger collections (books). Material is authored by people from all walks of life. Much content is created by university professors{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}, but the collection also contains very popular music content{{cite web |url=http://cnx.org/content/col10218/latest/ |title=The Basic Elements of Music |accessdate=30 November 2010 }} created by a part-time music teacher.{{cite news |work=CNN.com |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/TECH/11/08/connexions.learning/ |title=Throw away your school books: here comes textbook 2.0 |date= 8 November 2007 }} OpenStax CNX material is translated into many languages, aided by the open-content licensing. ==Copyright== To ensure the legal reusability of content, OpenStax CNX requires authors to license materials they publish under the [[Creative Commons]] Attribution License{{cite news |work=The New York Times |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/15/technology/15link.html?_r=1&ei=5070&emc=eta1 |title=Donât Buy That Textbook, Download It Free |date= 14 September 2008 |first=Noam |last=Cohen}} (presently, version 4.0). Under this license, the author retains the right to be credited (attributed) wherever the content is reused. The author grants others the right to copy, distribute, and display the work, and to derive works based on it, as long as the author is credited. ==Features of OpenStax CNX== *OpenStax CNX has content from all over the world in a growing variety of languages, not just materials from one specific school or university. It also collects materials to support education in K-12, community college, university, continuing education, and industrial training settings. *OpenStax CNX is globally accessible to anyone to not only read and use the materials, but also take them, customize them, and contribute them back to the repository or not. *OpenStax CNX is a grassroots organized from the bottom up rather than from the top down like many other open education projects. Everyone is free to join and take on a leadership role. ==Technical details== Three key factors enable the collaborative environment in OpenStax CNX: *Copyright licenses that preserve attribution but permit sharing: [[Creative Commons]] "attribution" licenses *Semantic markup of documents using [[XML]] (extensible markup language) so they can be searched for and combined. The markup language used is called âCNXMLâ.{{cite web |url=http://cnx.org/help/authoring/xml#cnxml |title=CNXML â Connexions Markup Language |accessdate=July 31, 2010 }} *Workspaces that facilitate collaboration by providing shared space, the ability to version materials and derive content from existing modules.{{cite web |work=Rhaptos Software Homepage |url=http://rhaptos.org |title=Open-source software developed and used by Connexions |accessdate=July 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724153058/http://rhaptos.org/ |archivedate=July 24, 2009 |df= }} ==Funding== The Connexions project was started in 1999{{Cite web|url = http://cnx.org/about|title = OpenStax CNX: About Us|date = |accessdate = 27 November 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} and initially supported by individuals and [[Rice University]]. That support has been substantially supplemented by grants from the [[William and Flora Hewlett Foundation]].{{cite pressrelease |publisher=Rice University Press Release |url=http://www.media.rice.edu/media/NewsBot.asp?MODE=VIEW&ID=11006 |title=Connexions wins $2M from Hewlett Foundation |date=15 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090820090348/http://www.media.rice.edu/media/NewsBot.asp?MODE=VIEW&ID=11006 |archivedate=20 August 2009 |df= }} ==See also== * [[OpenStax]], a library of free, peer-reviewed, and openly licensed college textbooks * [[Creative Commons]], the organization that created the licenses used by OpenStax CNX * [[Open educational resources]], the idea that educational resources can be shared in general through [[copyleft]] or other [[free culture movement]] licenses * [[OpenCourseWare]] * [[Open textbook]] * [[Bookboon]] * [[China Open Resources for Education]] * [[Curriki]] * [[Flat World Knowledge]] * [[Flexbook]] * [[Free High School Science Texts]] South Africa * [[Khan Academy]] * [[MIT OpenCourseWare]] * [[National Programme on Technology Enhanced Learning]] India * [[Open.Michigan]] * [[Tufts OpenCourseWare]] * [[Wikiversity]], a Wikimedia Foundation project, devoted to learning materials and activities ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|CNX}} * [http://cnx.org/ OpenStax CNX] homepage, '''cnx.org''' * [http://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/richard_baraniuk_on_open_source_learning.html TED Talk] Founder Richard Baraniuk discussing Connexions in February 2006 [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Rice University]] [[Category:Open educational resources]]

revision.comment: As project is completed, some corrections
revision.text:
The '''Pakistan-China Fiber Optic Project''' is a 820 kilometer long [[optical fiber cable]] laid down between the [[Khunjerab Pass]] on the China-Pakistan border and the city of [[Rawalpindi]]. It has been constructed as part of the [[ChinaâPakistan Economic Corridor]] at an estimated cost of $44 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=India Snubbed: Pak-China Initiate CPEC Project in Gilgit-Baltistan|url=http://www.thequint.com/hot-wire/2016/05/19/india-snubbed-pak-china-initiate-cpec-project-in-gilgit-baltistan|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=The Quint|date=19 May 2016}}</ref> Groundbreaking on the project took place on May 19, 2016 in the city of [[Gilgit]].<ref>{{cite news|title=PM inaugurates Pakistan-China Fiber Optic project|url=http://dailytimes.com.pk/pakistan/19-May-16/pm-to-inaugurate-fiber-optic-project-in-gilgit-baltistan|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=The News|date=19 May 2016}}</ref> The line was first envisaged in 2009,<ref>{{cite news||title=Pakistan To Deploy Fiber Optic Cable to Connect with China| last1=Khan|first1=Mehwish|url=http://propakistani.pk/2010/12/29/pakistan-to-deploy-fiber-optic-cable-to-connect-with-china/|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=ProPakistani|date=19 May 2016}}</ref> with Pakistan and China signing an agreement in 2013 to implement the project .<ref>{{cite news|title=PM performs groundbreaking of Pak-China optic fiber project|url=http://dunyanews.tv/en/Pakistan/337436-PM-performs-groundbreaking-of-PakChina-optic-fibe|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=Dunya News|date=19 May 2016}}</ref> However the project was not implemented until being included as part of the China Pakistan Economic Corridor. Placement of the line will take an estimated 2 years, and will bring [[3G]] and [[4G]] connectivity to the [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] region.<ref>{{cite news|title=India Snubbed: Pak-China Initiate CPEC Project in Gilgit-Baltistan|url=http://www.thequint.com/hot-wire/2016/05/19/india-snubbed-pak-china-initiate-cpec-project-in-gilgit-baltistan|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=The Quint|date=19 May 2016}}</ref>
The line will connect the [[Fiber-Optic_Link_Around_the_Globe#Europe_Asia|Transit Europe-Asia Terrestrial Cable Network]] with that of [[Pakistan]],<ref>{{cite news|title=PM performs groundbreaking of Pak-China optic fiber project|url=http://dunyanews.tv/en/Pakistan/337436-PM-performs-groundbreaking-of-PakChina-optic-fibe|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=Dunya News|date=19 May 2016}}</ref> which currently transmits its telecom and internet traffic through four undersea fiber optic cables, with another three undersea fiber optic cables under construction.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pakistan to Get $44 Million Fiber Optic Back Haul to Link with China|url=http://propakistani.pk/2015/12/03/pakistan-to-get-44-million-fiber-optic-back-haul-to-link-with-china/|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=ProPakistani}}</ref>
466.54 kilometers of the route will be located in Gilgit-Baltistan, while 287.66 kilometers will be laid in [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] province, 47.56 kilometers will be in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab province]], and 18.2 kilometers in [[Islamabad Capital Territory]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Pakistan to Get $44 Million Fiber Optic Back Haul to Link with China|url=http://propakistani.pk/2015/12/03/pakistan-to-get-44-million-fiber-optic-back-haul-to-link-with-china/|accessdate=19 May 2016|agency=ProPakistani}}</ref>
The project is financed by the Exim Bank of China at a concessionary interest rate of 2%, versus the 1.6% typical of other CPEC infrastructure projects.<ref name="brecorder.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.brecorder.com/market-data/stocks-a-bonds/0/1223449/|title=Economic corridor: China to extend assistance at 1.6 percent interest rate|work=Business Recorder|date=3 September 2015|author=Naveed Butt}}</ref>
The project has been completed and inaugurated in July 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/1756458/2-optic-fibre-cable-connecting-pakistan-china-inaugurated-today/}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:ChinaâPakistan Economic Corridor]] [[Category:Nawaz Sharif administration]] [[Category:Fiber optics|Cables]] [[Category:Optoelectronics]] [[Category:Optical telecommunications cables]]

[[File:Kitchen-Dough-Blender.jpg|thumb|Pastry blender]] A '''pastry blender''' is a cooking utensil used to mix a hard (solid) [[fat]] into [[flour]] in order to make [[pastries]].<ref name="Good Housekeeping">{{cite web|url=http://www.goodhousekeeping.com/cooking-tools/pie-making-tools-reviews/g270/pie-making-tools-pastry-blenders/?slide=1|title=Pastry Blenders|first=Sharon|last=Franke|work=Best-Tested Pie-Making Tools|publisher=Good Housekeeping|accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> The tool is usually made of narrow metal strips or wires attached to a handle, and is used by pressing down on the items to be mixed (known as "cutting in"). It is also used to break these fats (shortening, butter, lard) into smaller pieces. The blending of fat into flour at this stage impacts the amount of water that will be needed to bind the pastry into a dough.
==Alternatives== There are several alternatives to using a pastry blender. One is to work the fat into the flour with the fingertips, though this requires having a good "touch" and knowing just how lightly to work the fat into the flour without melting it.<ref name="Good Housekeeping"/> Another is to use two table knives like a pair of [[scissors]], one knife in each hand. A third is to use a [[food processor]].<ref name="Good Housekeeping"/>
==See also== *[[Dough scraper]] *[[Dough blender]] *[[Whisk]]
==References== <references/>
{{Pastries}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pastry Blender}} [[Category:Cooking utensils]]
{{Cooking-stub}}

[[File:Wikipedia PrvsC.JPG|thumb|A pervious concrete street]] '''Pervious concrete''' (also called porous concrete, permeable concrete, no fines concrete and porous pavement) is a special type of [[concrete]] with a high [[porosity]] used for concrete [[Concrete slab|flatwork]] applications that allows [[water]] from [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] and other sources to pass directly through, thereby reducing the [[surface runoff|runoff]] from a site and allowing [[groundwater recharge]].
Pervious concrete is made using large aggregates with little to no fine aggregates. The concrete paste then coats the aggregates and allows water to pass through the concrete slab. Pervious concrete is traditionally used in [[parking lot|parking areas]], areas with light traffic, residential [[street]]s, pedestrian [[sidewalk|walkways]], and [[greenhouse]]s.<ref name=ACIReport>{{cite web|title=Report on Pervious Concrete|url=http://www.concrete.org/BookstoreNet/ProductDetail.aspx?itemid=52210|publisher=American Concrete Institute|year=2010|isbn=9780870313646}} Report No. 522R-10.</ref><ref name=srmconcrete>{{cite web|title=Pervious Ready Mix Concrete|url=https://srmconcrete.com/ready-mix-concrete/pervious/|website=srmconcrete.com|accessdate=19 November 2015}}</ref> It is an important application for [[sustainable]] [[construction]] and is one of many [[Low-impact development (Canada/US)|low impact development]] techniques used by builders to protect [[water quality]].
== History == Pervious concrete was first used in the 1800s in Europe as pavement surfacing and load bearing walls.<ref name=FlDot>{{cite web|last=Chopra|first=Manoj|title=Compressive Strength of Pervious Concrete Pavements|url=http://www.dot.state.fl.us/rddesign/dr/Research/SA/FinalReport-3of4-Pervious-Concrete-Strength.pdf|publisher=[[Florida Department of Transportation]]|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref> Cost efficiency was the main motive due to a decreased amount of cement.<ref name=FlDot/> It became popular again in the 1920s for two storey homes in Scotland and England. It became increasingly viable in Europe after WWII due to the scarcity of cement. It did not become as popular in the US until the 1970s.<ref name=FlDot/> In India it became popular in 2000.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
== Stormwater management == The proper utilization of pervious concrete is a recognized [[Best management practice for water pollution|Best Management Practice]] by the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) for providing [[first flush]] [[water pollution|pollution]] control and [[stormwater]] management.<ref>[http://www.epa.gov/npdes/pubs/porouspa.pdf "Storm Water Technology Fact Sheet: Porous Pavement."] United States Environmental Protection Agency, EPA 832-F-99-023, September 1999.</ref> As [[regulation]]s further limit stormwater runoff, it is becoming more expensive for property owners to develop [[real estate]], due to the size and expense of the necessary [[drainage]] systems. Pervious concrete lowers the sites SCS Curve Number{{technical statement|date=May 2016}} by retaining stormwater on site. This allows the planner/designer to achieve pre-development stormwater goals for pavement intense projects. Pervious concrete reduces the runoff from paved areas, which reduces the need for separate stormwater [[retention pond]]s and allows the use of smaller capacity [[storm sewer]]s.<ref name=Water>{{cite web|last=Ashley|first=Erin|title=Using Pervious Concrete to Achieve LEED Points|url=http://perviouspavement.org/downloads/LEED_PointsAshley.pdf|publisher=National Ready Mixed Concrete Association|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref> This allows property owners to develop a larger area of available property at a lower cost. Pervious concrete also naturally filters storm water<ref>{{cite web|last=Majersky|first=Gregory|title=Filtration of Polluted Waters by Pervious Concrete|url=http://www.liquidassetdevelopment.com/HygienicWater.pdf|publisher=Liquid Asset Development|accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> and can reduce [[water pollution|pollutant]] loads entering into [[stream]]s, [[pond]]s and [[river]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pervious Concrete|url=http://www.purintonbuilders.com/pervious-concrete.aspx|publisher=Purinton Builders|accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
Pervious concrete functions like a storm water [[infiltration basin]] and allows the storm water to infiltrate the [[soil]] over a large area, thus facilitating recharge of precious groundwater supplies locally.<ref name=Water/> All of these benefits lead to more effective land use. Pervious concrete can also reduce the impact of development on [[tree]]s. A pervious concrete pavement allows the transfer of both water and air to root systems allowing trees to flourish even in highly developed areas.<ref name=Water/>
== Construction == Pervious concrete consists of cement, coarse aggregate and water with little to no fine aggregates. The addition of a small amount of sand will increase the strength. The mixture has a water-to-cement ratio of 0.28 to 0.40 with a void content of 15 to 25 percent.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=John T. Kevern |author2=Vernon R. Schaefer |author3=Kejin Wang |last-author-amp=yes |year=2011 |title=Mixture Proportion Development and Performance Evaluation of Pervious Concrete for Overlay Applications |journal=Materials Journal |volume=108 |issue=4 |pages=439â448 |publisher=American Concrete Institute |doi= |pmid= |pmc= |url=http://www.concrete.org/PUBS/JOURNALS/AbstractDetails.asp?srchtype=ALL&keywords=108-m47&ID=51683117 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130707064453/http://www.concrete.org/PUBS/JOURNALS/AbstractDetails.asp?srchtype=ALL&keywords=108-m47&ID=51683117 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 7, 2013 |accessdate=July 3, 2013 }}</ref>
The correct quantity of water in the concrete is critical. A low water to cement ratio will increase the strength of the concrete, but too little water may cause surface failure. A proper water content gives the mixture a wet-metallic appearance. As this concrete is sensitive to water content, the mixture should be field checked.<ref>{{cite web|last=Desai|first=Dhawal|title=Pervious Concrete â Effect of Material Proportions on Porosity|url=http://www.engineeringcivil.com/pervious-concrete-effect-of-material-proportions-on-porosity.html|publisher=Civil Engineering Portal|accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> Entrained air may be measured by a Rapid Air system, where the concrete is stained black and sections are analyzed under a [[microscope]].<ref name="Entrained Air">{{cite journal|last=Kevern|first=John |author2=K. Wang |author3=V. R. Schaefer|title=A Novel Approach to Characterize Entrained Air Content in Pervious Concrete|journal=ASTM International|year=2008|volume= 5|issue= 2|url=http://k.web.umkc.edu/kevernj/Articles/JAI101434.pdf}}</ref>
A common flatwork form has riser strips on top such that the [[screed]] is 3/8-1/2 in. (9 to 12 mm) above final pavement elevation. Mechanical screeds are preferable to manual. The riser strips are removed to guide compaction. Immediately after screeding, the concrete is compacted to improve the bond and smooth the surface. Excessive compaction of pervious concrete results in higher compressive strength, but lower porosity (and thus lower permeability).<ref name=Compaction>{{cite web|last=Kevern|first=John|title=Effect of Compaction Energy on Pervious Concrete Properties|url=http://www.rmc-foundation.org/images/PCRC Files/Construction Techniques/Effect of Compaction Energy on Pervious Concrete Properties.pdf|publisher=RMC Research Foundation|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref>
Jointing varies little from other concrete slabs. Joints are tooled with a rolling jointing tool prior to curing or saw cut after curing. Curing consists of covering concrete with 6 mil. plastic sheeting within 20 minutes of concrete discharge.<ref name=Operation>{{cite web|last=Kevern|first=John|title=Operation and Maintenance of Pervious Concrete Pavements|url=http://k.web.umkc.edu/kevernj/Articles/TRB%202011-PCPC%20Maintenance-Kevern%20(revised).pdf|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref> However, this contributes to a substantial amount of waste sent to landfills. Alternatively, preconditioned absorptive lightweight aggregate as well as internal curing admixture (ICA) have been used to effectively cure pervious concrete without waste generation.<ref>{{cite web|title = Internal Curing with HydroMax|url = https://indd.adobe.com/view/a243a57c-3fcc-4820-888c-95a5273088ce?ref=idm|publisher = ProCure|accessdate = 1 October 2012}}</ref><ref>Kevern, J.T. and Farney, C. â[http://procureusa.com/distributors/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Reducing-Curing-for-Pervious-with-SAP.pdf Reducing Curing Requirements for Pervious Concrete Using a Superabsorbent Polymer for Internal Curing.]â Transportation Research Record: Journal of the Transportation Research Board (TRB), Construction 2012, Transportation Research Board of the National Academies, Washington D.C.</ref>
== Testing and inspection == Pervious concrete has a common strength of {{convert|600|-|1500|psi|MPa}} though strengths up to {{convert|4000|psi|MPa|abbr=on}} can be reached. There is no standardized test for compressive strength.<ref>[http://carolinabomanite.com/custimages/PerviousSpecificationACI522108.pdf "Specification for Pervious Concrete."] ACI 522.1-08. American Concrete Institute, Farmington Hills, MI, 7pp.</ref> Acceptance is based on the [[unit weight]] of a sample of poured concrete using [[ASTM]] standard no. C1688.<ref>ASTM International. [http://www.astm.org/Standards/C1688.htm "Standard Test Method for Density and Void Content of Freshly Mixed Pervious Concrete."] Standard No. C1688.</ref> An acceptable tolerance for the density is plus or minus {{convert|5|lbs}} of the design density.{{clarify|reason=Pound is not a unit of density|date=July 2018}} Slump and air content tests are not applicable to pervious concrete because of the unique composition. The designer of a storm water management plan should ensure that the pervious concrete is functioning properly through visual observation of its drainage characteristics prior to opening of the facility.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
== Cold climates == Concerns over the resistance to the [[freeze-thaw]] cycle have limited the use of pervious concrete in cold weather environments.<ref name="Cold Weather">{{cite web|author1=Vernon R. Schaefer |author2=Keijin Wang |author3=Muhammad T. Suleiman |author4=John T. Kevern |title=Mix Design Development for Pervious Concrete in Cold Weather Climates |url=http://www.ctre.iastate.edu/reports/mix_design_pervious.pdf |publisher=Iowa State University |location= Ames, IA |year=2006}} National Concrete Pavement Technology Center. Report No. 2006-01.</ref> The rate of freezing in most applications is dictated by the local climate. Entrained air may help protect the paste like in normal concrete.<ref name="Entrained Air"/> The addition of a small amount of fine aggregate to the mixture increases the durability of the pervious concrete.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kevern |first=John |author2=K. Wang |author3=V.R. Schaefer |journal=Iowa State University|year=2008}}{{full citation needed|date=November 2015}}</ref> Avoiding saturation during the freeze cycle is the key to the longevity of the concrete.<ref name="Concrete Tech">{{cite web|title=Pervious Concrete and Freeze-Thaw|url=http://www.cement.org/tech/Pervious_print.html |work=Concrete Technology E-Newsletter |publisher=PCA |accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref> Related, having a well prepared 8 to 24 inch (200 to 600 mm) [[Grading (engineering)|sub-base]] and drainage will reduce the possibility of freeze-thaw damage.<ref name="Concrete Tech"/>
== Maintenance == To prevent reduction in permeability, pervious concrete needs to be cleaned regularly. Cleaning can be accomplished through wetting the surface of the concrete and vacuum sweeping.<ref name=Operation/><ref>{{cite web|title=Prevention|url=http://www.perviousconcrete.com/maintenance_prevention.htm|publisher=Charger Enterprises|accessdate=30 September 2012}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Green infrastructure]] *[[Permeable paving]] *[[Urban runoff]] *[[Impervious surface]]
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == {{Refbegin}} *US EPA. Office of Research and Development. [http://www.epa.gov/nrmrl/news/news102008.html "Research Highlights: Porous Pavements: Managing Rainwater Runoff."] October 17, 2008. {{Refend}}
== External links == *[http://npcpa.org/ National Pervious Concrete Pavement Association] *[http://www.perviouspavement.org/ Pervious Concrete Design Resources] *[http://www.concrete.org/technical/green-building-resources.htm American Concrete Institute]
{{Concrete navbox}}
